There are three types of cards next to the board: property cards (that show the property name, its value and its tax amount), soldier cards (that show the name of the unit, its value and its power rating), and chance cards (that need to be shuffled and put faced down next to the board).
On the board there are properties, soldier barracks and churches. When a player lands on a property, they can purchase it. When a property is purchased, if any other player lands on it, they have to pay the landlord a tax (written on the property card); also if the owner themselves lands on the property, they get that same amount from the treasury. The church tiles are chance tiles, and if a player lands on them they will have to draw from the chance cards. They can gain or lose coins from the chance cards.
The goal of the game is to get soldiers and gather an army. When a player lands on a soldier tile on the trail, if they have the required coin, they can add that soldier to their army.
The game ends when all the properties are sold, and the winner is the person with the most powerful army. The property value and the remaining coins are inconsequential. If the player with the most powerful army owes coins to the treasury or another player, they cannot be the winner and the second most powerful player will be the winner.
The visuals and the art style, as well as soldier units and properties, are themed around the Firefly Studios' 2002 real time strategy game "Stronghold Crusader".

name: Bubblebot
description:
There's been an accident in the Gear-Gum factory and all of the bots have been caught inside bubbles!

In Bubblebot, 2 players will compete in trying to keep their most valuable bots from floating away, while arranging the floated bots into sets and runs to keep their assembly line moving and maximum efficiency.

First to secure 20 Bubblebot orders wins!

—description from the publisher

name: Im Eulenwald
description:
Mice try to collect certain items in the forest, but on their way they have to move past tree stumps where the forst owl sleeps, and wake her up in the process.

If the owl is in good mood, the mouse may continue to move, if not, it must stop and it is the next player's turn.

The most notable feature of the game is a huge owl figure. Players can press its head, after which it will spread its wings and reveal either a friendly or an annoyed face.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Race, Turn Order: Progressive, Variable Set-up

name: Gladiator: Road to Rome
description:
Gladiator: Road to Rome is a fast-paced, solo or group card and dice game where players must battle each other or fight preset characters in the arena to survive.

Players choose one of 4 weapons and must strategically select cards to attempt to attack and defend themselves.

In solo campaign mode, your character is a captured Iceni warrior who must battle their way through 4 arenas against 16 increasingly difficult opponents to gain their freedom.

In Battle Royale mode, you fight other opponents to see who masters the arena.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Critical Hits and Failures, Dice Rolling, Once-Per-Game Abilities

name: Wyvern Moor: The Dungeon Crawl Card Game
description:
The next campaign set in the addictive Dungeon Crawl Card Game system. A stand-alone sequel to Kreel Manor: The Dungeon Crawl Card Game, Wyvern Moor sees bold heroes plunge into the perilous gloom of Wyvern Moor, and descend into the dark depths of the dungeons beneath.

In Wyvern Moor, players embark on daring quests and terrifying adventures as legendary champions of the stunningly beautiful World of Kilforth. Wyvern Moor is fully compatible with Kreel Manor, and includes another set of heroes and adventures featuring the same addictive Dungeon Crawl Card Game system.

—description from the publisher

name: Hoplomachus: Remastered – Pandora's Wake
description:
Once, long ago, a young girl was given a box and told not to open it. For the "crime" of curiosity, she was locked away, but now she's broken free and has no intention of ever going back.

Pandora's Wake is an expansion for Hoplomachus: Remastered featuring two brand-new arenas (including a remaster of the classic Hoplomachus Fa Mel Arena), each with their own unique game mode rules and units for solo and PvP play. This expansion also rounds out the combatants of Remastered by adding the Vesuvius faction, bringing it into cross-compatible parity with Hoplomachus: Victorum!
categories: Ancient, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Sports
publishers: Chip Theory Games, Lucky Duck Games, YOKA Games

name: Hoplomachus: Pandora's Might
description:
Not quite a part of Victorum, and not quite a part of Remastered, the Pandora's Might expansion bridges the gap between the two and brings a bevy of new heroes to the table in the fight against Pluto.

Usable in Victorum, this pack furnishes all your favorite heroes from Remastered with their own prowess deck, making them fully-functional now as both primus and hero.

Additonally, Pandora herself leads this intrepid band, but you may discover her powers to be a but more... unique. Use her at your own peril and try to balance the ability to earn practically any prowess in the game with the punishment of a flood of evil unleashed in the form of unrelenting scion influence. Pandora can also be recruited or drafted in some modes of Hoplomachus Remastered.
publishers: Chip Theory Games, Lucky Duck Games, YOKA Games

name: Hoplomachus: Victorum – The Forge
description:
A few new chips and Opportunity Cards.

Already known:

Opportunity Card: Foul Nemesis
Opportunity Card: Forge of the Lion
Opportunity Chip: Farouk the Smith
Bane Chip: ???
publishers: Chip Theory Games, Dice Realm, Frosted Games, Lucky Duck Games, YOKA Games

name: Bacon Card Game
description:
In Bacon, the goal is simple: collect bacon! But how do you achieve that? By fattening up adorable piglets and then, well, you know... It's easy to learn, quick to play, and full of laughter-inducing moments that'll have you squealing with delight.

Unleash strategic chaos with 71 action cards that keep your opponents on their toes. Fatten up 20 unique piglet cards, each with its own adorable design, to create your bacon empire. Keep track of your progress with 29 bacon score cards, and dive into the game with confidence using the comprehensive rulebook.

—description from the designer

name: VOID: The Cooperative Card Game
description:
VOID is a tactically-satisfying cooperative card game. In it you play a member of the crew of the ISS Shoemaker on the first crewed interstellar voyage in human history. Something has gone terribly wrong, and your jump engine has thrown the ship wildly off-course. Now you and your crew must work together to survive the many dangers of space and find your way back to Earth, our home.

In VOID, you are the crew of a starship with six systems. Each system has a resource you must manage; replenish the resource to keep the system functional or deplete it to use the system's ability. If ever a system is depleted with no resources left, it goes into failure and causes lasting problems until repaired (on top of losing access to it's system ability). Perhaps the most important system is the Engines, whose system ability allows the ship to jump one step closer to home.

Complicating the crew's mission are Event cards, one of which is drawn every turn. Sometimes, Events are neutral or even positive, but oftentimes they present the players with new challenges, as they deplete systems, cause damage to crew or even risk chain reactions. A Special kind of Event called a Mission Card is drawn each time the crew Jumps. There are nine Mission Cards in all in a given mission (chosen randomly from fifteen for variety) and once the crew has resolved the last of the nine, the Mission is successful. If the crew runs out of event cards or all systems go into failure, then the Mission has failed.

All the art and rules text of VOID are released under a creative commons license (CC By SA 4.0 to be exact).

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Events, Variable Player Powers

name: Kampf
description: Each player gets 22 figures: 1 king, 1 field marshal, 1 flag, 2 knights, 2 canons and 15 soldiers. The canons are placed in the castles. The different kinds of figures move in different ways about the crossing points of the grid. The objective of the game is to capture the enemy king. Capturing is done by moving over an enemy figure to a free space behind it.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Pattern Movement, Square Grid, Static Capture

name: Arzium Archive Promo Box
description:
An add-on available during the Creature Caravan Gamefound campaign.

Includes these promos:

33 promo cards

NEW Islebound: Emerald Edition Promos (10 cards)
Underground Buildings

Above and Below (17 cards)
Essen 2016
Groves
Megaland
Mystic's Hut
Watch it Played

Near and Far (6 cards)
Handy Headwear
Pandoran Box

name: Creature Caravan: Wanderers
description:
Includes components for a 5th and 6th player, extra dice, and 45 creature cards.

The expansion includes a new type of card: items. Items can be "equipped" to creature cards, as long as the creature has the required type. Many of the item abilities activate when a die is placed on the creature that they're equipped to.

Backers of Creature Caravan will receive this expansion for free but Wanderers expansion will be available for purchase separately at a later date.

name: Where Many Were
description:
Where Many Were is a fast-playing set of big battle rules for the American Civil War that fits on just two pages.

Each base/element represents one battalion or regiment, and while they’re centred in the combat rules, command and control relies on divisional, corps, and army generals successfully manoeuvring their brigades. This lets brave & lucky units shine – as they did historically – while players grapple with the difficulty of commanding armies far larger & better-armed than their inherited staff systems were prepared for – as generals did historically!

The game features:


Central “poker dice” mechanic keeps a Western flavour to all resolution.
Command initiative system that introduces battlefield friction and even makes solo play fun and challenging.
Simple but layered unit characteristics that interact flavourfully on the table, but can quickly be used to translate historical orders of battle into playable rosters.
Integrated casualty and morale mechanics to keep the game flowing.
A roster sheet to easily track the details of your force.


-Description from the publisher's website
categories: American Civil War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: MGs & Bayonets
description:
MGs & Bayonets is a fast-playing set of WWII infantry battle rules that fits on just two pages. In addition to its featured period, it also works well for Interwar and early Cold War skirmishes.

Players control a 1:1 platoon or company of soldiers following a historical ORBAT, and play focuses on holding and denying terrain features on the table. With simple gradation between raw and veteran units, commanders can stack the odds in their favour before launching their final assault, just as captain and lieutenants did historically!

The game features:

A simple bidding system of command initiative that lets the hasty move before the coordinated.
Terrain-centric movement and shooting rules that organically incorporate reconnaissance by fire and area suppression.
Integrated casualty and morale mechanics to keep the game flowing.
An optional points system for pick-up or club play.


-Description from the publisher's website
categories: Book, Korean War, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: That Bleak Armada
description:
That Bleak Armada is a generic set of rules for everyone who just wants to get their spacefleets on the table!
The author’s group have played battles with up to 60 ships a side in 2-3 hours.

The game’s simple activation system pushes decisions on players every phase, providing believable results on an ordinary-size table (assumed to be between 4’x4’ and 6’x4’). It also makes the game suitable for solo play.

All measurements are from the ship’s “stem” or centre, so any scale of ship can be used. Similarly, the flexible (somewhat abstract) ship design system lets you easily create & price a profile for any ship you like!

No matter the galaxy you’re fighting in, whether you’re firing lasers or solid shot, That Bleak Armada lets you indulge your interstellar megalomania with a fun, fast game that’s easy to learn but hard to master.

-Description from the publisher's website
categories: Aviation / Flight, Book, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: BOHICA: Vietnam Skirmish Rules
description:
BOHICA: Vietnam Skirmish Rules Bend Over, Here It Comes Again is designed for platoon size actions for figures of any scale.

Includes rules for the nasty surprises you'd expect, and practice scenarios
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Tali: Character Expansion
description:
When added to the basic game of Tali, enough components for 10 Players.

Includes:
4 Unique Historically Based Character Cards
4 Character Tokens
40 Historical Punch out coins (3 Denominations, 8 gold, 12 silver, 20 copper)

name: Guess Who Coasters
description: By asking a series of yes-or-no questions, try to identify which character your opponent is holding before they can identify yours!

name: Raiders of the Color Compass
description:
Roll and Write (chose&color) puzzle adventure race game. Players try to find 7 pieces of the lost ark by traveling around the map. Whoever finds the ark first is the winner. Players have a limited number of rounds per game. When traveling, they use a map that is divided into hexagonal tiles representing 5 different types of terrain with different color. Infinity number of players with no delays. Turn-based gameplay but players are active also in other player's turn.Solo variant included.Very short set up time.“Coloring” part for relax time.
Competetive and/or cooperative play.Only one d6 for solo play needed.Variable Player Powers.

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Adventure, Dice, Exploration, Fantasy, Horror, Print & Play, Puzzle, Racing, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, End Game Bonuses, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Paper-and-Pencil, Race, Solo / Solitaire Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Insel der fünf Kapitäne
description:
The game is based on an escape room principle where the players need to resolve different types of puzzles in order to proceed to the next level.

It is a mixture of an interactive computer game and a detective story with real objects pieces of evidence that survived over time.

What do you receive?

- Game materials
- Game instructions
- Mobile App

How it works?

- The game works on digital devices. The digital game is mainly used to get instructions and to enter the solutions to the questions
- The rest of the game takes place with real objects (it's not a card game!)
- Game duration 90-120 min
- Similar to the escape rooms concept the game can be played once
- Can be played again by other players

Game options

It is possible to play the game in several modes:
- As one team (Standard mode)
- Against the time
- Multiple team competition mode: additional game sets required which you can print with no additional cost. You will not receive any spoilers or indication for solutions so you can take part in the game

What is required?

- Preparation time: ~15 min
- Internet access
- Registration on our portal www.idventure.de, App and game download
- Curiosity, fun, "out of the box" thinking

We wish you an unforgettable experience with the game!

—description from the publisher (translated

Beame dich und deine Gäste auf dem Schiff ans Ende der Welt zu fahren und fühle dich wie Jack Sparrow!

Mit dem iDventure Spiel "Insel der 5 Kapitäne" begeben sich die Partygäste auf hohe See und in die Untiefen der Rätsel und Geheimnisse, die sich um die Entdeckung Amerikas ranken. Um den großen Inka-Schatz zu finden, müssen die Spieler die Rätsel des alten Piratentagebuchs lösen.

Das Spiel basiert auf wahren Gegebenheiten und auf Legenden von bekannten historischen Persönlichkeiten. Es enthält Lehrinhalte aus Geschichte, Mathematik, Geographie, Sprache und Logik und spannende Abenteuergeschichten.

Das iDventure Spiel funktioniert auf PCs, Tablets, Smartphones oder anderen digitalen Geräten. Das digitale Spiel dient hauptsächlich dazu, Videos mit Anweisungen zu sehen und die Lösungen auf die Fragen einzugeben.
Der Rest der Schnitzeljagd findet mit realen Gegenständen und Spielobjekten statt.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Book, Murder/Mystery, Party Game, Puzzle, Real-time, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Paper-and-Pencil, Pattern Recognition, Role Playing, Storytelling

name: Para bellum: Proelii
description:
Standalone playable expansion of Para bellum (formerly Scharz).
The game provides optional battle expansions for the Para bellum games, but also provides separately playable historical battles:
The first of them - the Battle of Zama in 202 BC.
The system works with different types of units (different attack, lives, movement points), their experience (dice rolls, bonus lives), but mainly from the energy of the units. The first battle of the game - Zama, 202 BC, is a prime example of a dynamic asymmetrical battle with lots of tactical decisions and twists. All this without hidden information.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Movement Points, Re-rolling and Locking, Simulation, Square Grid, Tile Placement, Zone of Control

name: Monopoly: Ferrero Sonderedition
description:
LET'S GO!
Let luck accompany you and make a fortune in the world of real estate! Roam the streets and grab the most profitable streets, squares and land, invest in houses and hotels to keep your cash register ringing. Negotiate with other players and participate in auctions. And above all: always stay on your toes! Only then can you avoid bankruptcy and be the winner in the end.

MONOPOLY, the famous game about the big deal, takes you through the fabulous world of chocolate with this special edition.

—description from the publisher (translated)

LOS GEHT'S!
Lass dich vom Glück begleiten und mach ein Vermögen in der Welt des Immobilienhandels! Zieh durch die Straßen und schnapp dir die gewinnträchtigsten Straßen, Plätze und Grundstücke, Investiere in Häuser und Hotels, damit deine Kasse immer klingelt. Verhandle mit anderen Spielern und nimm an Versteigerungen teil. Und vor allem: Bleib immer auf Zack! Nur dann kannst du dem Bankrott entgehen und am Ende Sieger sein.

MONOPOLY, das berühmte Spiel um den großen Deal, führt dich mit dieser Sonderedition durch die fabelhafte Welt der Schokolade.

—description from the publisher

name: Victims and Vandals
description:
Players travel between Highway, Camping, Neigbourhood and Beach squares, and draw a card indicating whether they've become a vandal, witnessed vandalism, or been a victim of vandalisation. You have insurance, but they're not happy if you're a victim - and if you become a vandal you're likely to pay a fine or spend a couple turns in jail. Collect two cards from each environment to win.

Produced by the John Howard Society, for intervention purposes.

name: Terra Formars: Extension
description: Adds 4 cards (51-54) and a marker.

name: Partner Swap
description:
Teams compete to guess the mystery word , action, or item faster than their competition. This game is for adults only, the mystery items are naughty, naughty, naughty!

One team member either draws, acts out, or sculpts the clue while the rest of the team guesses. Correctly guessing results in collecting point tokens.

But be careful! Your partner may want to swap you out with another person on the opposing team that has more point tokens! No worries, you get a new partner also!

name: Siege of the Citadel: Dark Legion Bonus Pack Expansion
description:
Includes the following Dark Legion level Kickstarter stretch goals.

Includes:

Bonus Game Tiles
Cybertronic Hero – Attila III figure w/card
Mishima Hero – Yojimbo figure w/card
Metropolitan Prophets figures w/card x2
Mercurian Maculator figure w/card
Tekron figures w/card x3
Defiled Avatar w/card x2
Whitestar Faction figures w/cards x4
Malignants figures w/cards x5
Golgotha figure w/card
Karak the Keeper figure w/card
Defense Turret figures w/card x2
Brotherhood Seeker Indigo figure w/card
Reinforcement Heroes Set #1 w/cards
Player Dashboard
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Siege of the Citadel: Doomtrooper Bonus Pack Expansion
description:
Includes all of the Doomtrooper level Kickstarter stretch goals.

Includes:

Bonus Game Tiles
Chibi Edward Murdoch Figure (for Super Dungeon Explorer) w/card
Blood Beret McBride Figure w/card
Pam Afton Figure w/card
Pride Figure w/card
Alakhai Figure
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Siege of the Citadel: Extra Game Tiles
description: Includes 8 double-sided tiles for use in The Siege of the Citadel board game.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Siege of the Citadel: 3D Wall & Hallway Connector Pack
description: Includes 2 3D walls and a set of hallway connector tiles for Siege of the Citadel.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Neo-Dorado: la expedición
description:
Mysterious events occur in a jungle region of the new kingdom of Granada (Colombia), you are sent to investigate the area
Take the role of an explorer in the era of the post-conquest of America (1783), enter a hostile territory, compete against other players, collect resources, create objects, and fight against native monsters. Some explorers may survive or the
monsters may defeat them.

—description from the designer

misteriosos sucesos ocurren en una region selvatica del nuevo reino de granada (Colombia), eres enviado a investigar la zona.
Asume el papel de un explorador en la epoca de la post-consquista de america(1783), entra en un territorio hostil, compite contra otros jugadores, recolecta recursos, crea objetos, y lucha contra monstruos autóctonos, puede que algun explorador sobreviva o puede que los monstruos los venzan.

—description from the designer (Spanish)
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Hand Management

name: Operation Rolling Thunder: Air War Over North Vietnam, 1965-1968
description:
Operation Rolling Thunder is a simulation game that recreates the historical bombing campaign conducted by the US Air Force and the US Navy over North Vietnam during the period spanning from 1965 to 1968. The game accommodates both solitaire and cooperative play (in which one player assumes command of the US Air Force, while the other oversees operations of the Navy (with an option to play in semi-competitive mode)).

The core objective for the player(s) is to inflict enough infrastructural damage to compel North Vietnam to engage in peace negotiations while disrupting the flow of troops and resources that sustain the insurgency in South Vietnam via the logistics network known as the Ho Chi Minh Trail.

The overarching campaign is divided into seasonal phases, wherein the player or players determine which objectives have been identified as potential targets for the current phase. They then calibrate the scope and composition of air raids, aligning missions with their chosen strategic imperatives. Decisions entail prioritizing missions, including tasks like safeguarding raids against enemy fighter interception through combat air patrols, neutralizing enemy ground-based air defenses, deploying strike capabilities to maximize damage on specified targets, and the hunting down of opportunity targets. Through the use of cards, players resort to a repertoire of historical tactics, specialized missions, selective target assignments, and technological assets to optimize raid efficiency and protection. The augmentation of US forces occurs incrementally, encompassing both numerical reinforcements and advancements in equipment. This includes the introduction of advanced-technology missiles, reflecting an evolving military landscape. Additionally, pilots progressively gain experience, achieving exceptional proficiency in specific mission types.
Targets of interest encompass oil and supply depots, military installations, industrial facilities, the railroad network, crucial bridges, and pivotal airfields, whose destruction bears varying consequences for North Vietnam's ability to generate supplies, mobilize forces, transport equipment, and defend its airspace. Consequently, players may experiment with different approaches, all the while remaining mindful of the alignment of their decisions with the underlying strategy implied by the Joint Chiefs of Staff target list. Higher-priority targets are invariably more robustly defended, necessitating a close monitoring of incurred losses; unacceptable levels can severely compromise or even prematurely shut down the campaign.
After recording the damage (on the game map) inflicted by US air raids on North Vietnam's war-making capacity, the player or players retain the option to dispatch armed reconnaissance missions, scouting for opportunity targets en route to the South, and may call upon the formidable B-52s from the Strategic Air Command to administer targeted strikes on the mountain passes leading to the Ho Chi Minh Trail and on the trail itself.

In tandem with the military dimension, the game incorporates a 'political layer.' Herein, players contend with the constraints imposed by fluctuating directives emanating from the White House, driven by apprehensions of potential escalation involving China and the Soviet Union. These directives can manifest as stricter rules of engagement, prohibited targets, or specific mandates. In response, players challenge the political echelons for operational freedom, judiciously selecting the campaign aspects where enhanced flexibility is warranted.

The player or players face a difficult challenge reminiscent of the historical endeavor, which fell short of achieving its primary objectives. Despite the severe humanitarian toll inflicted by the campaign, it failed to fracture the resolve of the North Vietnamese people and its leadership, who exhibited exceptional resilience in the face of sustained aerial bombardment. The Vietnam War persisted for several more years, culminating in the well-documented denouement.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Semi-Cooperative Game, Simulation, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Разрушители замков (Сastle hassle)
description:
Will the young knights be able to defend their castle and attack their opponent?
All players move at the same time. Goal of the game: destroy one central or 2 side towers of the opponent, while maintaining your castle.
The game progress is divided into two steps: “Preparation” and “Battle”.

"Preparation"


Players decide which actions they want to implement this turn and place their action tokens on the appropriate space on their castle board. On his turn, the player can attack the opponent's tower, defend his own towers, or extract gold from the mines.

"Battle"


All players simultaneously raise their screens, compare the number of tokens on the strike, defense and mine cells, applying their effects. The game ends as soon as one of the players destroys 2 side or central towers. The winner is the player who destroyed the opponent's castle without having his towers destroyed as much as possible.

—description from the publisher

name: Shadow of the Obelisk: Favour of the Gods
description:
The Gods have taken an interest in your building endeavours!
This opens up new opportunities for the pious and crafty - but also comes with new rules to keep your eye on. For when building is over, your heart will be weighed and the Gods will judge the balance between its purity and taint.
A new board where you can test your heart, being pure or tainted. Tainted spaces will give benefits during the game, but if you don't balance them with pure action spaces, you will get negative points. Moreover there is a new game sheet for drawing your obelisk.
categories: Ancient, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play

name: Bits & Bytes
description:
In Bits & Bytes, you play as a computer trying to defend itself from computer viruses launched at you by a hacker. Use cards to keep the viruses at bay and destroy all of them to win the game! With varied cards, several difficulty levels and different ways to end the game, Bits & Bytes is perfect for solo gamers, computer geeks and more looking for a fast, simple solo game.

—description from the publisher

name: Fireteam Zero: Stalag V
description: KS exclusive map pack for multi-squad scenarios.

name: Fireteam Zero: Red Sands
description: KS exclusive map pack for multi-squad missions.

name: Stadt Land Fluss für Potter-Fans
description:
"City, Country, River" is one of the greatest games since the invention of pen and paper - but where is the magic? Here it comes! The legendary "Instead of Land, River" now appears in a version especially for Potter fans!

Many categories related to Harry Potter, the Alley of Angles and Co. provide variety as well as exciting additional rules. And with the game boards sorted by themes and different difficulty levels, there is guaranteed to be something for everyone who is still eagerly awaiting their letter from Hogwarts.

—description from the publisher (translated)

»Stadt, Land, Fluss« ist eines der großartigsten Spiele seit der Erfindung von Stift und Papier – doch wo bleibt eigentlich die Magie? Hier kommt sie! Das legendäre »Statt Land Fluss« erscheint nun in einer Version extra für Potter-Fans!

Viele Kategorien rund um Harry Potter, die Winkelgasse und Co. sorgen ebenso für Abwechslung wie spannende Zusatzregeln. Und mit den nach Themen sortierten Spielplänen und verschiedenen Schwierigkeitsstufen ist garantiert für jede*n etwas dabei, der immer noch sehnsüchtig auf seinen Brief aus Hogwarts wartet.

—description from the publisher

name: Fuchsjagd
description:
The fox is the player who rolls the highest number. He gets a head start by rolling three dice once and starts running from the starting point at the ski hut in any way he wants. During the hunt, before returning to the starting point, he must definitely get to a red dot on the top of the mountain. The hunters have to cut off the fox's path back to the starting point, because if he reached it he would win the game. At the same time, they should try to surround the fox so that he can no longer move. He would then be trapped and lose.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race

name: EvoHom
description:
EvoHom transports players millions of years back in time to test their skills as ancestral human populations (hominins) with elements of semi-cooperation, worker placement, and a unique dice rolling mechanism that models genetic recombination.

Each game takes a unique journey through human evolution, starting with a randomized environmental scenario that is based on scientific research into climates where hominins thrived.

Cooperate with other player’s hominin populations to gather food to survive, compete for opportunities to grow your population, and introduce genetic variation into your population to change your physical traits (phenotypes).

Utilize your actions, with some surprises along the way, to evolve and grow your population to best fit the environment!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action/Event, Dice Rolling, Semi-Cooperative Game, Worker Placement

name: Minotaur Maze
description:
Minotaur Maze immerses players in a mystical labyrinth where four adventurers undertake an adventure to collect treasures while navigating an (3D) shifting maze, outsmarting the Minotaur and using skill cards to outsmart your fellow players.

The primary goal with four players is to be the first to collect 5 treasures (cards) out of the total of 17 available treasures
The game challenges players to strategically place tiles into the maze, use their skill cards and the use of the Minotaur to emerge as the winner of Minotaur Maze.

—description from the designer

name: Archaeoastronomy
description:
This game was created so everyone can experience in a fun way how the ancients felt about their world.


You will understand how important the cycles of the day and night skies and sky events were to the ancients, and how it effected everything they did.
It will also test your knowledge of the moon, the planets, myths and world archaeoastronomy architecture, artifacts and alignments.
You are learning the cycles of the sun by actually moving the sun as you play. The Sun moves very closely to how we experience the sun moving in our world.
You will understand how the sun cycles signal the seasons of the year to the ancients. They had approximate ways of telling time like candles, water clocks and dividing daylight into 12 hours no matter what time of year it was. The Sun and Stars were extremely important to them.
You will get to play around with being a good leader, a bad leader and a complicated leader


How the game is played:

Earth Goal (board 1):


The player chooses a Star Map (leader or ruler) that will decide which building, star totem and constellation they'll be. This decides what geographical location their Sol Cards (trivia questions about archaeoastronomy) will have in their deck.
The goal is to get your construction site, your building, your totem, and the sun (flashlight) to all line up during your turn. Once that's done, you can now go to the Heaven Board and become a 'God on Earth.'


Heaven Goal (board 2) and to Win:


To have one or 2 jewels, depending on if you choose to just have fame for one generation or a constellation forever named after you and you are known for a thousand years. It is up to the player to decide what kind of win they want.


Actual Mechanics, Earth Board:

The Sun is moved every month (all players take their turn) and the Festival Card the Sun is pointing at is played. After the player plays what the cards says,

if the player gets a correct question card, you can roll the die and move. If it's incorrect, it goes to the next player.

If it's a Star & Fortune card, then the player does what it says.

Actual Mechanics, Heaven Board:

The time is the same as the earth board and you move with the sun. You take a Heavens card every turn and do what it says. There is messing with the Earth Board cards, messing with other players and earning and losing jewels.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Multiple Maps, Questions and Answers, Turn Order: Progressive

name: Big Bash Smash
description:
A limited edition release, Big Bash Smash was the official tabletop game of the Big Bash Cricket Series and claims to be the "best of cricket games smashed up and delivered in a quick, sharp and explosive tabletop game for the whole family".

Big Bash Smash offers three different game mode. Play a traditional match in Twenty20, be the first to 50 runs in the 50 Run Challenge, or see who can score the most runs in one over in a Super Over game!

Fans can also download a free scoreboard companion app, keep score with a digital scoreboard and capture the action with a slow-motion replay, just like the real thing.

This game borrows very heavily from the layout and style of the traditional and original TEST Match game, but with a few major differences. The mat is round and very colourful, with sponsors names printed on it and the 'fences' are simple freestanding cardboard, which do not surround the field. The mechanics of the bowler are also quite different in that the ball is ejected from the front of the stand by a spring lever, rather than being 'bowled' by the figure itself.

name: Skill & Fate
description:
Manage your warband, explore your surroundings and face your opponents in this fast paced skirmish wargame!

Skill & Fate is a skirmish wargame system that allows you to focus on interesting decisions instead of dealing with minutia of rules and tedious bookkeeping.

What makes Skill & Fate different is its focus on free form movement and fluid turn structure. Whenever you move your figures, you move them in a straight line until terrain stops you or you decide to stop. Whenever you're moving inside line of sight of an opponent, they may try to interrupt you and take an action. Combat is resolved by drawing cards with defense icons, and damage is marked by figures themselves (by making them prone or removing them from the board).

All you need to start playing is 12 cards per player, 12 beads or tokens (to mark command points), handful of miniatures and some terrain, all of which can be downloaded and printed out before shelling out money.

—description from the publisher
categories: Exploration, Fighting, Miniatures, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Interrupts, Line of Sight, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Peacemakers: Horrors of War – Shared Nightmares
description: 10 new horror cards, which can be added to the game to increase the variety of horrors encountered further.
categories: Adventure, Animals, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Medieval
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Deadly Dinner: Kaviar Kills
description:
Tech billionaire Alan Tusk wants to celebrate his latest success with caviar and champagne: In a week, he plans to embark on the first manned flight to Mars. Among the guests on his luxury yacht are not only movie stars, celebrated sportsmen and -women or business magnates, but also several of Alan's old school friends. When Alan's body is found in his suite that evening, the celebration ends as a fiasco. Who could have done such a gruesome deed?

Deadly Dinner – Kaviar Kills is a classical murder mystery game: Enjoy a dinner (or just some snacks) with your family and/or friends, while all of you take on the role of a murder suspect. One of you committed the murder, but you all have secrets you would rather keep. Try to find out the secrets of the other guests without making yourself suspicious. Your goal is to solve the murder case … or get away with the bloody crime. Apart from the murderer trying to cover their tracks, every player also has a secret task they have to complete during the game.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Acting, Deduction, Hidden Roles, Role Playing, Semi-Cooperative Game, Storytelling

name: Numba
description:
Apples, bananas, oranges and strawberries!

Choose a number card as the Numba card for this game. Turn over fruit cards and shout Numba! when you spot that number of fruits.

Collect all the cards to win the game!

—description from the publisher

name: Foxy Brawlers
description:
Foxy Brawlers is a game of wits, conflict, deception, and adventure. A player must traverse the entire map and get to the finish, from where the Devil commands his forces and put an end to the little evil.
There can only be 1 king and there is only 1 crown, don't let others stand in your way. You may team up and scheme against other players, but beware of the knife in the back as only one of you can reach the finish.

All players traverse the map by rolling the die and moving the rolled amount. After everyone has made their turn all players engage in a fight with a boss. Boss fight ends when a sole survivor remains, who will get 2 turns on the map after the fighting is done, so make sure other players lose.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Interrupts, Player Elimination

name: Sahkku
description:
In the northern regions known as Scandinavia live the indigenous Sami people. They play a running fight game called Sahkku. It’s popularity there is shown by the annual championship games and prestigious trophies they give to the winners. The game may be as old as 1,000 years or more, and simulates a battle between two groups of warriors. These warriors start the game asleep, and before they can enter the battle they must be awakened by a specific role of the dice. Thereafter, they move and capture opposing pieces by ending their turn on an occupied space. The path can be blocked by opposing pieces, sending them back to their starting row. There’s also a fickle King with special powers in the game, who joins up with either side when captured. A very different kind of game - one of only a few known to history

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Tobit
description:
Tobit is a 2-player strategy game from the Republic of Khakassia in central Asia. The age of the game is unknown, except that it’s been a tradition in the region for many generations. The game board is interesting in the lack of corner spaces, and the odd number of rows in most examples. The pieces start the game as expected, on the near rows of spaces. It’s basically played like orthogonal Checkers, like other Middle Eastern jump-and-capture games. The difference appears when a piece reaches the far row and is promoted to a Tobit. Tobits can move like chess rooks and make long jumps to capture. Once they leave that back row, however, they lose their Tobit status. It’s a very fun game for all ages, right alongside Checkers.

—description from the publisher

name: Rhombus
description:
The game of Rhombus begins with a large empty table space surrounded by two to four players, and each player holds a hand of three Rhombus cards. These cards are printed with geometric shapes in several colors, and the challenge is to play these cards to the table to form diamond shapes (rhombuses). Forming such shapes in different sizes and color combinations scores points, and it's possible to form multiple rhombuses with a single card placement. The colorful array of cards grows to cover the table until the last card is placed and final score tallied. Fast fun for all ages!

—description from the publisher

name: Poland: A Valiant Defense. The Soviet attack of September 17th, 1939
description: This is a solitare, print and play system, that currently focuses on the Soviet invasion of Poland in 1939. It is a hex and counter game that places you in command of a few squads of Polish troops as they try to slow the tide of Soviet invaders. Play time for each scenario shoud be about 45 min.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Not A Hero
description:
In a world where heroes are celebrated, you are not the hero – you are the unsung hero of the realm. Choose your role as a townsfolk character and work with your fellow players to survive and lead the heroes to beat the Big Bad Elder Dragon.

Gameplay: In "Not A Hero," players harness the power of their decks each turn, strategically collecting valuable information and gold. These precious resources empower their townsfolk to wield influence over the heroes, guiding them to embark on quests and enhancing their abilities and skills. But beware! As heroes conquer monsters, unearth treasures, and accomplish quests, the looming Elder Dragon threat intensifies. Mismanagement of the heroes can trigger devastating strikes, leading to the town's destruction and ultimate defeat. The townspeople's path to victory lies in nurturing their heroes to the point where they become mighty enough to vanquish the Elder Dragon.

name: Waifus Arena
description:
Welcome to Waifu Arena: Kawaii Battles! A card game in which the prettiest waifus face each other in intense and exciting duels. If you're a fan of fast-paced, strategy-driven card games with spectacular art, this project is for you!

The most beautiful girls with unique powers, are the very essence of this world. However, an evil has arisen that threatens to unbalance: The Noctas, dark creatures that seek the destruction of the world. Now, it is time for our Waifus to fight and prove who is the ultimate waifu.

—description from the publisher

name: Shelly's Pearl
description:
Enjoy exploring the ocean floor with your dive team collecting colorful shells to trade with Shelly the octopus in Shelly's Pearl! This early learning Life & Thinking Skills game is intended for ages 4 and up and helps young players achieve goals and practice strategy while building fine motor skills. Play Shelly’s Pearl with 2-4 players in as little as 10 minutes.

Shelly the octopus uses “they/them” pronouns. Shelly’s personal pronouns are shared only in the instruction booklet. The game does not utilize pronouns in the gameplay but does provide the opportunity to discuss personal pronouns if desired.

—description from the publisher

name: Shore Seekers
description:
Shore Seekers utilizes the theme of turtle migration to help engage kids across numerous math levels, from addition to early multiplication.
Shore Seekers is good for developing addition skills as players roll up to three dice, one at a time, adding the revealed numbers with the goal of reaching a sum equal to or less than seven.

Shore Seekers also helps with early multiplication skills when a player has rolled two or three dice, they multiply the sum of their dice by the number of dice rolled.

Players take turns rolling the dice, trying to reach a sum of seven or less. Based on the roll, each player then moves their turtle around the island. Whenever a turtle reaches or passes the entrance to the nesting site (space 21), it lays as many eggs as shown on the top clutch card. At the end of the game, the player whose turtle has laid the most eggs wins.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Moguls & Dominion
description:
Step into the world of Moguls & Dominion: The Real Estate Rivalry, where up to six players are invited to engage in an epic showdown of wit, strategy, and ruthless ambition. In this immersive board game, you'll navigate the complex landscape of real estate and business, all in the pursuit of becoming the ultimate tycoon.

Your objective is clear: build an empire of properties and businesses using cunning strategies, shrewd deals, and the occasional betrayal. As you traverse the competitive terrain, alliances will be formed, deals will be brokered, and rivalries will ignite in a battle for supremacy.

'Be the Mogul,' strategically acquiring properties and amassing wealth through astute real estate decisions. Alternatively, choose the path of 'The Dominion,' focusing on lucrative business ventures that can secure your financial dominance. The game offers diverse avenues to success, but be prepared to face the consequences of your choices.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Auction: Turn Order Until Pass, Catch the Leader, Connections, Cooperative Game, End Game Bonuses, Income, Open Drafting

name: Hazel's Helpers
description:
Join Hazel and her siblings as they practice their beaver lodge-building skills. Players take turns rolling the die to determine their actions; connecting logs to create their lodge; moving cattails, or rolling the rock toward another player's lodge. The first player to use all 10 of their logs to build their lodge wins the game.

Fine motor skills are practiced as players connect individual log pieces to build unique structures and roll a rock, trying to avoid the cattail blockers on another player’s board.

Decision-making skills are practiced as well. Considering potential benefits or risks, players make decisions such as how to connect their log pieces, which duck they choose, and which player’s board they will roll the rock toward.

—description from the publisher

name: Jeu des alpinistes
description:
Players take on the role of mountaineers seeking to be the first to reach the top of a mountain.

The game is played in two phases. In the first, players gather equipment by advancing along a track using a dice. Part of the equipment is mandatory for phase 2, while the other part is optional but will provide bonuses for phase 2.

Each player decides individually when he has enough equipment to attempt the climb. He chooses the most appropriate route and advances according to a roll of a dice. Different dices are used depending on the weather. The first player to reach the summit wins the game.

It's largely a game of luck, with sort of a stop-and-go mechanism for the transition from the 1st to the 2nd phase (either start climbing early but with minimal equipment, or spend more time on the 1st phase to get better equipment and climb faster). There's also an element of interaction, which consists of swapping equipment with another player, either in phase 1 (where only duplicate cards can be picked), or in phase 2 (where even another player's single cards can be picked).

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Different Dice Movement, Events, Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Take That

name: Blazed: Cannabis Card & Dice Game
description:
Blazed is a one-of-a-kind, interactive and unpredictable cannabis smoking game combining risk strategy and luck.

Players take turns rolling dice to earn points and collect cards for toppling opponents in a race to 10,000. Once this milestone is reached, all players get one final turn to score as many points as possible before final scores are tallied. While a victor is eventually crowned, everyone wins when you get Blazed!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling, Race

name: Scrabble: Dr. Seuss
description:
A whimsical twist on the traditional word game, Scrabble: Dr. Seuss puts your knowledge of the classic children’s books to the test!

Like the original Scrabble game, you can play regular Scrabble words, or you can lay down your favorite whimsical Seussian words to score the most points.

Customize each game with Dr. Seuss cards and Better Letter Battles to flip over any tile as a blank and maximize your moves!

Oh What a Rhyme Time you can have! It's time to rhyme in this Seussian spin on the classic crossword game! Scrabble: Dr. Seuss welcomes fans of these timeless books to play the traditional way, or play with added Seuss'd up bonus features! Relive your favorite stories and discover new ways to play in this whimsical edition of Scrabble!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Hand Management, Spelling, Square Grid, Tile Placement

name: Dance Dance Dance
description:
Turn up the music to find out who’s got the best moves. Combine the movements assigned to your hands, feet and head, preferably with your own signature dance moves, into a dazzling performance to the beat of a song chosen by others.

The dancer who scores the most points from the judges wins the title of Ultimate Dance Master. Remember that everyone can dance, including you!

Game includes 100 dance cards and a Pointualizer 3000 point slip pad.

name: El Capitán Trueno
description:
This game is inspired by the popular Spanish comics series of the same name. Capitán Trueno is a knight errant in the era of the 3rd Crusade (ca.AD 1200) who travels the world with his companions to fight bandits, tyrants and other evil characters. His companions are his young squire, the astute Crispin, his strong friend, the robust Goliath, and the Viking princess Sigrid.

The premise of the game is that Sigrid has been captured by a gang of Orcs and is now held in a Dungeon. The players have to travel along a game track through desert, jungle and into the Dungeon. The first player to reach Sigrid sets her free and wins the game.

At the beginning the players get a set of 'assistance cards'. The game track has fields with obstacles which you can pass by a die roll or by discarding a card. Other fields can give you new cards.

An unusual twist is that many of the hazards, such as orcs, snakes or skeletons, are represented by counters. Each player controls a set of these that he can move to harass the other players.

name: Firebirds: FAC
description:
Firebirds: FAC is a tactical-level, narrative-style solitaire wargame using a tables-based game engine.

As the pilot of a US Army L-19 Bird Dog Forward Air Control (FAC) plane, your ultimate goal is to survive a 1-year Vietnam tour of duty during the year 1968, while at the same time trying spot and mark hidden enemy Viet Cong units in FAC zones, then later calling in air strikes to take them out.


The following dice are required to play: One D20, one D6, and two D10s.
5 minute game setup and breakdown times.
A medium size table is recommended for game setup.
Total play time to complete a full 1-year tour of duty takes approximately 3-10 hours (depending on game length chosen).
Adjustable starting difficulty based on player's skill level.
For game support, please be sure to visit the Black Cat Wargames Facebook group


With most of the rules integrated into the tables, there is practically no learning curve or rules memorization. And with numerous crewmen skills, detailed damage modeling, weather effects, terrain types, random events, and a multitude of table modifiers, Firebirds: FAC offers high replay value.

Are you up to the challenge of surviving a 1-year tour of duty in Vietnam?

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Print & Play, Vietnam War, Wargame

name: Europa-Städte Spiel
description:
Two dice are rolled. Everyone has 2 game pieces, which are differentiated by color for each player. The players take turns to roll and move.
The 40 city cards are shuffled at the start of the game and distributed to the players. Each player must touch the cities of their city cards with their two tokens (one or the other) and thus discard the city card in question. When a double is rolled, the following rules apply:
2x6: discards one of their city cards of their choice.
2x5: exchange one of your cards with the cards that were not dealt.
2x4: you can roll the dice again.
2x3: you have to skip the dice once.
2x2: pays one token into the cash register.
2x1: receives a city card from the player on the right.
Whoever touches all of the cities on their cards and is the first to put down their cards is the winner.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Struggle for hegemony in Eastern Europe
description: The game covers the years 1558-1667. There are 12 moves in the game. It is built on a card engine. And in its essence it resembles Here I Stand and Virgin Queen.Players can declare wars and enter into alliances. Alliances allow players to share both cards and troops. Throughout the map, large-scale events will take place that affect all countries. For example, the Deluge in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, the Troubles in the Russian Kingdom, the Thirty Years' War in Germany.Also, each move gives certain advantages to both one side and weakening the other.The game is very balanced. The author tried to convey this historical period as accurately as possible. The game requires 4-5 players.But in the future the author is thinking of adding more scenarios. Many events reflect the state of a particular state in a given period of time. Winning battles can provide benefits, but the player must not forget about diplomacy. If you are not protected by your allies, then any war you have will be doomed.

name: Tee Masters
description:
Combining on-the-spot strategic decisions, along with exciting press-your-luck, competitive gameplay, Tee Masters gives golfers and non-golfers alike a set of engaging, continually evolving challenges, combined with fast-action gameplay that makes players call for “one more round!” as soon as the game ends. Just grab the Tee Masters custom dice, tee up on its 18 killer holes, and find out which friends and family rule the course!

Scoring mechanic of Tee Masters is simple to understand, but not necessarily easy: just match three of the Scoring Dice you’re rolling on a hole, and you get that score on the hole. And you’ve got three “Group Rolls” with all the dice, you set aside rolls you like as you move through those rolls, and you build up your best score for the hole. In short: three tries to nail the lowest score possible for the hole.

But in Tee Masters, the Scoring Dice don’t just have pars, birdies and eagles. Unfortunately, they also feature more damaging scores like +1 bogeys, +2 double bogeys, and even the dreaded +3 triple bogey.

And then there’s the Shot Die, and that adds hole hazards like sand traps, wind, and water, and the dreaded DUFF, which can derail a great score in an instant. But the Shot Die also delivers “Great Shots,” which can help you improve your score on a hole, big time.

And in addition to its super-charged multiplayer gameplay, Tee Masters also plays great for one player. Because gameplay is so fast and straightforward, you’ll find yourself hitting the Tee Masters course when you’ve got ten or so minutes of spare time, just to see if you can achieve a new personal-best score.

Go for eagle, or play it safe? Avoid hazards, don’t duff, and navigate each hole like a boss. Tee Masters is a fantastic challenge for golfers and non-golfers alike. At home, at game night, with fellow golfers at the clubhouse, or on vacation, Tee Masters is a great time for 1-4 players, or even teams.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Re-rolling and Locking

name: NOT Sorry
description:
Race around the board to reach your goal first, but watch out! – your opponents could change the landscape at any moment.

The modular board grows or shrinks to fit the number of players. The individual boards rotate in response to players' decisions, requiring them to adapt quickly or fall behind.

Simple rules and the modular board lead to fast turns and ever-changing strategies, making the game perfect for both children and adults.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Modular Board, Point to Point Movement, Take That, Variable Set-up

name: Battles: Napoleonic
description:
Battles: Napoleonic is a 1-2 player tactical skirmish wargame depicting infantry warfare in Europe between France and England during the early 1800s.

The game features 5 different soldier types, 3 types of battles, and 10 battle maps.
Campaigns consist of either 5 or 10 random linked skirmish battles.
For solitaire players, the game offers an advanced AI bot opponent which makes calculated decisions based on its current situation.
Features such as day/night, weather, line of sight, 7 terrain types with movement/cover effects, and ranged/melee soldier attacks are also included.


One D6, one D20, and two D10 dice are required to play. A dry erase pen is also required.
Solitaire or 2 players.
5 minute game components setup and breakdown times.
May be played on a small size table.
Adjustable difficulty based on player's skill level.
Total campaign play time is approximately 2.5-5+ hours (depending on campaign length chosen). Individual battles can last between 15-45 minutes.
For game support, please be sure to visit the Black Cat Wargames Facebook group


With most of the rules integrated into the tables, there is practically no learning curve or rules memorization. And with 5 soldier types, 10 battle maps, randomized enemy soldiers setup (single-player), an advanced AI bot opponent (single-player), randomized enemy soldier skill levels (single-player), small table footprint, and quick setup/breakdown times, Battles: Napoleonic offers an entertaining game for players of all skill levels, plus high replay value.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: The Curse of Candelabria: 6th Player Expansion
description:
The House of the Chimaera is ready to emerge from the mists of the north to unleash its fury on the lands of Candelabria! The House, given its strong bond with nature and the unknown, boasts powerful mystical powers and the ability to pass through roads and paths unknown to most. This House has its own initial Region, which is added on the main board as an expansion tile to the original game board. This also raises the player level count to 6.

The Explorations:

Inside the package you will find 18 exploration tokens, each depicting one or more different icons. These represent the mysteries and discoveries that the Houses make as they wander through Candelabria, when they decide not to plunder the territory but to see what is in front of them.

During the Set-Up these tokens are to be placed face down, randomly, on each territory belonging to a region that is not identified as the initial Region of a House (whether or not this is present in the game).

When a model (Candle or Castle) of a House enters a territory containing a token, he can INSTEAD of deploying a Land Flame and then perform the action relating to the territory, take the Exploration token, placing it face down next to his House Board. He may then reveal one of his exploration tokens as part of any action he takes to obtain the benefits indicated on this, or keep it covered to gain 1 VP at the end of each Year for each face-down token in his possession.

name: The Curse of Candelabria: Solo Mode
description:
With this expansion the single-player mode is introduced, that is the possibility for a player to unleash the power of the houses in six scenarios of increasing difficulty. Taking on the role of a different house each time, the player will have to confront increasingly stronger and more ruthless enemies to achieve the ultimate victory.

Each scenario has a predefined set-up, where the initial forces of the house are extremely small and are confronted against one or two other houses, scattered throughout the lands of Candelabria. The player, with a limited number of moves, will have to defeat all the forces present on the game board positioned around his goal or, alternatively, defeat all the Candles of the houses present on the board to triumph.

Although it follows the basic rules of the game, this mode has some exceptions, such as:

The Solo-Mode uses the 1-3 player side of the Game Board;
The game does not end in 3 Years: the Years progresses as the player deploys and maneuvers, with different rules depending on the scenario and the difficulty. Each scenario can affect: the starting Year, how many moves are needed for the Year to progress, the maximum Year a player can reach;
Opposing Houses can have more than 1 Land Flame per Territory: the enemy Houses can field more than one Land Flame per territory. It could happen in many ways (sometimes from the very beginning, depending on the scenario);
Tactic Cards are discarded once used: each Tactic Card is discarded after a single use, and can not be acquired again. The symbols regarding the increase in initiative are translated into reading the battlefield better (see next area);
90 unique cards are introduced, to guide the actions of the enemies both in and out of combat. Each scenario will state when the out-of-combat actions of the enemies are taken, and from where the cards are resolved, while in combat the same cards act as a double tactic card that will try to harm the player depending on the theme of the card and the effect resolved;
Some unique rules will be added to every scenario, like different winning and losing conditions depending on the narrative and the events that are taking place.

New Mechanics: Mountains

Within the expansion we introduce a new game mechanic: the mountains. This mechanic provides three-dimensionality to the game plan, expanding the strategic possibilities and limiting the movements of the opponents, creating a completely different map placing tiles.

Mountains are high ground, impassable by normal methods, which separate the territories they are placed between by breaking regions in half, or by separating two regions completely. These separations are to be positioned where indicated.

While small divisions might seem little, they’re the key to hinder the development of an enemy force, create choke points and manipulate the map a little more, gaining the full value from movement and bringing out the strength of explorers.

name: The Curse of Candelabria: Missions and Decay
description:
A new deck of 40 cards that adds the Mission and Decay mechanics to the game

“Missions and Corruption” is package containing 40 mini-cards divided into 24 Mission cards and 16 Decay cards that adds two mechanics and a twist to the game. This package and the mechanics contained are usable in every player count, with different twists and applications.

First, the Missions. While the King’s gone, every House has many nobles and factions that wants to sit on the throne. This groups sent private letters and requests to the Houses, searching for an help in exchange for their support. Other make their trouble known to all the Houses, in hope that someone comes and help them out.

Mission cards are cards with a specific request on them, be it to kill a candle, build a temple or control a specific region. By completing the request, the players can receive Victory Points to help them gain some edge in the war for the throne of Candelabria.

Every player will receive two Mission Cards at the beginning of a game, during Set-Up. One of the two cards is taken by the player in the form of a private mission, a secret objective that he needs to accomplish, while the other card is placed near the board and create a set of mission that all the players can access to. As a side note, two types of missions are available:

Yearly missions, which can be completed once a year.
Ranking missions, where the reward can be taken by the first three players.
While the personal mission will award points only to the player that possess the mission, the common ones will be claimed through one of this methods. The idea behind this is to create a pool of changing milestones and objectives for the players to interact with, giving other ways to gather Victory Points and have fun while strategizing around that. This will help giving substance to the Turn Order too, since now the advantage for the first player would not only be to win draws but also the be able to complete an objective first, and thus giving some weight to the combat choices of getting initiative.

Second, the Decay. The ones closer to the power are the ones that first melt. Since the Houses tried to subdue the Curse with sacrifice, Decay has spread into their ranks, changing their values and slowly chipping at them.

Decay cards are cards with specific effects, similar to tactics cards. Their usage, although, is different. Decay cards are received every time a player try to win influence over a Course but fails, during the combat phase. These cards are placed on the War Board and modify the effect on that until the current War Season is over, giving a new tactical asset and effects to the Houses.

Decay is a mechanic with the intent to lessen the burden for a failed bet or wrong move on the Curse, by giving not an advantage but the chance to play around new effects and get a well-deserved revenge (with enough strategy and intelligence).

name: Battles: South Pacific
description:
Battles: South Pacific is a solitaire tactical skirmish wargame depicting Australian Commando operations against the Imperial Japanese Army in the Solomon Islands during 1944-1945.

The game features 7 types of missions and 10 battle maps. Solitaire campaigns consist of either 5 or 10 random linked skirmish battles, including missions such as Bridge Demolitions and Officer Assassinations.
The game features an advanced enemy IJA AI bot opponent which makes calculated decisions based on its current situation. Other features such as day/night, weather, line of sight, suppression, and 7 terrain types with movement/cover effects are also included.
Players will be able to improve their Commandos by assigning them a variety of skills, plus equip them with numerous types of weapons and equipment before each mission.

Game Features:

Solitaire play.
One D6, one D20, and two D10 dice are required. A dry erase pen is also required.
5 minute game setup and breakdown times.
A medium size table is required for play.
Adjustable starting difficulty based on player's skill level.
Total campaign play time is apporoximately 2.5-5+ hours (depending on campaign length chosen). Individual battles can last between 15-45 minutes.
For game support, please be sure to visit the Black Cat Wargames Facebook group


With most of the rules integrated into the tables, there is practically no learning curve or rules memorization. And with 8 enemy unit types, 10 battle maps, an advanced AI bot opponent, randomized enemy IJA setup, randomized enemy IJA skill levels, moderate table footprint, and quick setup/breakdown times, Battles: South Pacific offers an entertaining game for players of all skill levels, plus great replay value.

—description from the publisher
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Hound Dog
description:
A speed-based game.

One player rolls dice and holds the cup, the others have bones-on-a-string sitting in a circle on the board. When a named number or doubles are rolled, the player with the cup tries to trap the bones in the cup before they're snatched away. If you trap a bone, you get a chip from its owner. Player with the most chips after a decided-upon amount of time, wins.

name: L'autostop
description:
Bronze medal @the invention international contest of 1951 by Edmond Dujardin.
This is a board game with cards exhibiting road signs. The player must get ride of all the cards he gots at the start of the play by playing them each time he reach a step on the board. he is allowed to play the card if the steps allows him.

name: Pugilat de ruelle 2
description:
A game of Jordy Questeur, illustrated by Simon de Thuillières.
Bare-handed fighting card game, one versus one, based on anticipation, probabilities, and risk taking.
As it can be played for up to 777 years old, that means it's a miraculous game.
Note : the author makes jokes in his game, like "pugilat de ruelle" (street pugilist in the middle Ages) for street fighter 2 (in the modern world).

Un jeu de Jordy Questeur, illustré par Simon de Thuillières.
Jeu de cartes de bagarre à mains nues en un contre un (ou autrement dit : une bagarre a deux avec estourbissement), basée sur l'an Ticipation, les pro Babil Lités (deux noeuds plats six fer tous chez), et la prise de risk.
Particularité : on peut y jouer jusque 777 ans, ce qui en fait un jeu miraculeux du même coup.

name: Battles: Vietnam
description:
Battles: Vietnam is a solitaire tactical skirmish wargame depicting US Army Ranger operations against the Viet Cong in South Vietnam during 1969.

The game features 4 types of missions and 10 battle maps. Solitaire campaigns consist of either 5 or 10 random linked skirmish battles.
The game features an advanced enemy Viet Cong AI bot opponent which makes calculated decisions based on its current situation.
Other features such as day/night, weather, line of sight, suppression, air strikes, and 6 terrain types with movement/cover effects are also included.
Players will be able to improve their Rangers by assigning them a variety of skills, plus equip their Ranger Team with numerous types of weapons and equipment before each battle.

Game Features:

Solitaire play.
One D6, one D20, and two D10 dice are required. A dry erase pen is also required.
5 minute game setup and breakdown times.
A medium size table is required for play.
Adjustable starting difficulty based on player's skill level.
Total campaign play time is apporoximately 2.5-5+ hours (depending on campaign length chosen). Individual battles can last between 15-45 minutes.
For game support, please be sure to visit the Black Cat Wargames Facebook group


With most of the rules integrated into the tables, there is practically no learning curve or rules memorization.
And with 10 enemy soldier types, 10 battle maps, an advanced AI bot opponent, randomized enemy Viet Cong setup, randomized enemy Viet Cong skill levels, small table footprint, and quick setup/breakdown times, Battles: Vietnam offers an entertaining game for players of all skill levels. Plus it offers high replay value.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Battles: Western Europe
description:
Battles: Western Europe is a 1-2 player tactical skirmish wargame depicting American Army operations against the German Army during the Battle of the Bulge in the Belgian Ardennes from November 1944 to January 1945.

The game features 3 types of missions and 10 battle maps. Campaigns consist of either 5 or 10 random linked skirmish battles, including missions such as Meeting Engagements and Defending Towns.
The game features an advanced enemy German Army AI bot opponent which makes calculated decisions based on its current situation.
Day/night, weather, line of sight, suppression, and 6 terrain types with movement/cover effects are also included. Players will be able to improve their units' skill levels by doing well on the battlefield.

Game Features:

Solitaire or 2 players.
One D6, one D20, and two D10 dice are required. A dry erase pen is also required.
5 minute game components setup and breakdown times.
A medium size table is required for play.
Adjustable starting difficulty based on player's skill level.
Total campaign play time is approximately 2.5-5+ hours (depending on campaign length chosen). Individual battles can last between 15-45 minutes.
For game support, please be sure to visit the Black Cat Wargames Facebook group


With most of the rules integrated into the tables, there is practically no learning curve or rules memorization.
And with 10 enemy unit types, 10 battle maps, an advanced AI bot opponent, randomized enemy German Army setup, randomized enemy German Army skill levels, moderate table footprint, and quick setup/breakdown times, Battles: Western Europe offers an entertaining game for players of all skill levels, plus great replay value.

—description from the publisher
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Survival Stories: The Cottage – Through the Woods
description: In this DLC you will live a parallel story to the main plot of the game, where you will feel the fear in your adventure through the woods of Connieville and its surroundings.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Murder/Mystery, Print & Play
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Narrative Choice / Paragraph, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Die Fuchsjagd
description:
The players take turns to roll and move. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players. The first to reach space 80 wins the game.

The game was published in the 1920s as promotional giveaway for "Leipziger Textil-Gesellschaft m.b.H." in Chemnitz.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Smart10: 80-talet
description:
Questions about the 80s.

—user summary

En uppsättning nya frågekort till SMART10: 50 dubbelsidiga kort med 100 nya frågor och 1000 nya svar!

Temat är 80-talet med sina kändisar, musik, trender, TV-program, politik och mycket mer. Byt ut frågekorten i Smartboxen mot två förpackningar temafrågor eller blanda dessa frågor med hälften av de ursprungliga frågorna. För att ha glädje av dessa frågekort behövs också Smartboxen ur SMART10 eller SMART10 JR.

—description from the publisher

name: The Sun, The Sky, and The Stars
description:
The Sun, The Sky, and The Stars is a 2-4 player, family-friendly, point trick-taking game for all ages. Follow Kyupi on his adventure through the stars.

The game includes 50 cards: 3x10 cards (value of 1 to 10) for each Sky, Sun and Stars suit cards and also 20 "Kyupi" cards, which function as "Event" cards, that can change the current win condition.

Each player is dealt 6 cards. Each turn one player leads by playing one card. The other players have to follow the suit (Sun, Sky, Stars) if possible. If not they can try to trump with another suit or play a "Kyupi" card to change the rules. The suits trump each other in a rock-paper-scissors style and all trump the "Kyupi" cards. After 6 turns the round is over, shuffle up and re-deal. Who has the most points after 3 rounds is the winner!
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Aegeapolis
description:
Welcome polī́tēs in classical Greece!
Your leadership is urgently requested! Guide the fortune of the naval power of Athens, the belligerent Sparta, the trading giant of Corinth or the seven-gated Thebes.

You decide how you want your civilization to succeed. Should Sparta become a democracy with strong maritime trade? Should Corinth conquer the Peloponnese? Should Athens become the home of World Wonders?
Everything is possible - you decide!

The game is played on a map with the historical cities, poleis and rural areas.
Aegeapolis is an economic game at its core. You can trade, expand your capital and increase your income by this means. You can coexist peacefully with the other civilizations.
You can capture neutral cities, accumulate cultural goods and build World Wonders.
You can also commit acts of piracy, conquer enemy poleis (cities) and even capture an enemy capital to force an early end of the game in your favor!

To win the game, earn victory points by constructing buildings in your capital, conquering cities, acquiring trade goods and cultural assets, and bragging about your wealth!
categories: Ancient, City Building, Civilization, Economic, Nautical, Pirates, Political
mechanics: Action Points, Auction: Turn Order Until Pass, Dice Rolling, Income, Movement Points, Moving Multiple Units, Negotiation, Pick-up and Deliver, Resource to Move, Trading, Turn Order: Pass Order, Zone of Control

name: Project HELIX
description:
The prophecy has been fulfilled. The Earth will soon become uninhabitable. The only chance is to build a space station and find our new home, the New Earth. The HELIX project is designed to allow players to build their own space station, each controlling a company. Whoever manages their resources best can build a bigger and more efficient space station. But to win, you have to be able to get the resources, and it's important to make efforts in planetary exploration.

Each turn, you roll dice as many times as you want to get resources to build your own space station. With a push your luck mechanism, if you roll too much, you fail. But if you don't take risks, you progress more slowly... Then activate the space station moduls you've already built. Activating these can create countless combinations and chain reactions, giving you access to new resources and opportunities on your own board. Whoever has the most victory points at the end of the game wins!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Push Your Luck

name: Pirate Hunter: 1718
description:
Pirate Hunter: 1718 is an old-school style tactical solitaire board game of action and adventure, with a bit of wargame and RPG elements mixed in. An open-ended sandbox style game where you, as a warship captain, may choose your own path.
