Someone's Y is a limited communication deduction word game. Everyone is a vowel, but someone's 'Y,' and they're trying to blend in with the other vowels! Test your vocabulary and see if you can deduce who's 'Y!'

For 4-6 players, Someone's 'Y' is fast and easy to learn. Players take turns saying a word. If a word is said with your vowel in it, you can choose to take a token. However, 'Y' can choose to take a token whenever they want. But be careful - you don't want to give away too much information about what vowel you have because if 'Y' is caught at the end of the round, they have one last chance to win by guessing every other player's vowel!

-description from publisher
mechanics: Communication Limits, Deduction, Hidden Roles, Semi-Cooperative Game, Voting

name: Park Photography
description:
You and your family show up together at the park, “let's have a competition,” one of them suggests. “Let's all split up and take photos of the scenery. First one to take all their photos and get back to the car wins.” You all happily agree, heading out along the path to take pictures of trees, benches and ponds.

Park Photography is a leisurely game for 2-4 players about taking photos in the park. In this game you will be exploring the park, and trying to be the first of your family to make it back to the car (after taking some great photos of course). Be careful when taking photos though, you don’t want to have too many pictures of the same things.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Grid Movement, Square Grid, Tile Placement

name: Chilli or Chunder: Pepper X Finale
description:
This micro expansion provides an alternative Round 5 finale chilli pepper, the new Guinness World Record breaking "Pepper X".

Weighing in with over a million more on the Scoville scale compared to the previous Guinness World Record holder, the Carolina Reaper, attempt to devour this in three bites if you dare!

—description from the designer
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Party Game, Print & Play
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers

name: Eldritchwood
description:
In this original, solo, folk horror adventure game set in Medieval times that never were, you do not control a single character, but all the 36 Notables of Eldritchwood.

Like a storyteller, you weave a story of relationships, daring actions, deadly combat and difficult choices, moving from one character to the next as the story unfolds.

Hunt foul beasts like the Tatzelwurm or the Basilisk, meet supernatural entities like the Dust or Blackheart the Prince of Rats, learn magic from grimoires, socialize during events and festivities, get married, run from the Inquisition, and above all fight the evil that is threatening the lives and sanity of the good folks of Eldritchwood.

To play, you need this book, a pair of standard six-sided dice, a pencil, and a planner to keep track of events and dates.

—description from the designer

name: Guinness Pub Quiz Trivia Card Game
description:
Enjoy these unique Pub Quiz questions just about anywhere: at home, at a friends, at your favorite pub, anywhere friends gather! Answer correctly to win the card. The first to collect 5 cards wins the round!

The player rolls the dice to determine which category they will be quizzed on.

Starts with "G": answers contain a word that starts with G
Game People Play: answers are recreation or sports themed
Since 1759: answers are about history since the start of Guinness
Anything Flows: answers are about anything
Pubular Culture: answers are about popular culture
Players Choice: player chooses which category (1-5) to be quizzed on
Unique and unusual questions are sure to keep everyone intrigued.

Set contains 100 Pub Quiz Cards (with 500 questions and answers) and one die along with a set of instructions.

—description from the publisher

name: El juego de la guerra
description:
Each player starts the game with 5 card in their hands, and after a card is played a new one is drawn from the pile.

Every turn each player plays a card in the table. The player with the maximum points in their card wins the round and get all the cards in the round. In case of a tie, the player who first played the card wins.

When there are no enough cards for all the players in the draw pile, the rest of the cards in their hand are played and the battle finishes. The played with the highest number of points (not cards) wins the battle.

When 3 battles (or 2 consecutive ones) are won, the player gets the "Gran Cruz al Mérito de la Guerra" Medal and wins the game.

Players can play individually, in pairs or even in asymmetrical mode. In this last case, the player playing alone draw cards in a different fashion: he can have a look at the two card on the top and get the one desired (the the one one returns to the top of the pile).

If a player wins a round and the gets the "Jefe de todos los ejércitos" (12 points) card and the 2 "General" (10 points each) cards he wins the battle. In the case that he additionally has a Cruz Roja (Red cross, 10 points) card and a plane (9 points) card, he wins the battle and the rest of the players discount one won battle from their merits. In the case that none of the other players had a previous won battle the winner obtains 2 battles and thus, get the "Gran Cruz al Mérito de la Guerra" card, winning the game.

name: Linked words
description:
A twist on Scrabble that includes two game kinds using a roulette:

Firstly, you can play using the included roulette that obliges you to play your next word under a specific restriction:

Begging of an already placed word
Middle of an already placed word
End of an already placed word


Secondly, you can start the game with the tiles upside down and turn as many tiles as indicated in the roulette. Then, you create a word using letters shown, taking all letters used with you. The rest of them remain for the next rounds.

—user summary

name: Heroes of Ilirium: Dual Deck Duels
description:
Welcome to the grand arena of Heroes of Ilirium: Dual Deck Duels – a game where strategy meets fantasy, and where every choice you make shapes the fate of Ilirium!

In this dynamic 2-player card game, you don't just choose a hero – you draft two! And with 8 distinct heroes to pick from, the combinations are vast and strategies limitless. Our unique dual deck system breaks the convention: players wield not one, but two decks, each teeming with a diverse range of monsters and versatile utility cards. As you venture deeper, you'll find that each hero evolves, not just in story, but in power. With the collection of Soul tokens, heroes level up across three stages, each unlocking potent abilities that can sway the tide of battle.

But the intrigue doesn't end there. Every round unfolds on a new and unpredictable battleground. Tame wild beasts not native to your decks, harness their strengths, and surprise your opponents. While the heroes stand back from direct combat, their growing powers cast wide shadows over the battlefield, influencing duels and determining outcomes.

Are you ready to experience a game like no other? Dive deep, strategize, and become the master of dual deck dueling!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Drafting, Card Play Conflict Resolution

name: The Great War: The Front
description: A card-based simulation where players will be assigned command of a front during World War 1. They will receive orders and will be assigned forces to execute those orders. While there will be brutal attrition, a well-executed strategy will mean the difference between death or victory on The Front.
categories: Card Game, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Command Cards, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Turn Order: Pass Order

name: City of Glory: Card Game
description:
A cooperative game of 4 villages employing laborers (with the help of elephants, buffalo, artisans, chisels) to harvest rice, build a central temple, avoid invasions and establish a monarchy.
You have to complete the temple and fill the thrones before the deck (or rice) runs out. But build too fast and events may overwhelm you!
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Civilization, Farming, Religious
mechanics: Communication Limits, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Solo / Solitaire Game, Worker Placement, Different Worker Types

name: Iron Age
description:
Iron Age is a classic empire-builder with modern mechanics set in the European Iron Age. The goal is to forge your empire’s legacy to ensure its place in history.

Expand by war and diplomacy, recruit epic Heroes, build marvelous Wonders and make brilliant Discoveries to collect Victory Points and effects that strengthen your empire.

Players adapt their abilities by managing their selection of Battle and Command Cards in their hand. Some are replayable each turn and some are handed to the targeted opponent after play.

Conquer the world as Rome, Greece, Persia, Egypt, Carthage or Gaul, each with their own set of 3 Heroes, a starting Discovery and a unique Legacy Bonus.

Each turn has 3 phases - Income, Action and End - and there's a maximum of 8 turns per game. If a player reaches maximum expansion or claims enough achievements, the game will end early.

By the end of the game, the player with the most Victory Points is declared the winner and earns the title "The Great".

Clever planning and a silver tongue is required to sneak up on victory without being spotted and rushed by the opponents before it is too late.

Iron Age is approachable grand strategy in a small box. It features casual gameplay with intense competition. Entertainment and loud outbursts guaranteed.

Based on engine building, worker placement and hand management.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Movement, Command Cards, Hand Management, Negotiation, Worker Placement

name: Tira e Molla
description:
Rivivete tutte le emozioni della trasmissione televisiva dell'anno!

Tra quiz pazzi, avvincenti prove musicali e gare di mimo, potrete misurare la vostra abilità con quella degli avversari. Ma nella prova conclusiva sarà tutto rimesso in gioco, con colpi di scena veramente imprevedibili!

Relive all the emotions of the TV show of the year!

Between crazy quizzes, exciting musical tests, and mime competitions, you will be able to measure your skill with that of your opponents. But in the final test, everything will be put back into play, with twists of scene truly unpredictable!

name: Flapjacks & Sasquatches: North Forest Stash
description: The North Forest Stash expansion contains 41 cards for the main deck of Flapjacks & Sasquatches. The cards include tools, treasures, implements, utensils, helpers, and friends. A single "Bacon" die is included.

name: Flapjacks & Sasquatches: Salute to Bill & John
description:
A pair of promo cards for Flapjacks & Sasquatches. These were released as an appreciation for two Northwoods Heroes on the occasion of the passing of the Prolific Games axe.

The following promo cards are included:

"The Rules Say So... Now!"
"Bork Bork Bork"

name: Beyond Kuiper
description:
Beyond Kuiper is a game of space fleet combat for 1-6 Players. Each Player starts in command of a starship with a customizable captain and crew. when the battle starts each player must maneuver their crew to best operate their spacecraft and ensure it is functioning at the highest possible level. Defeat your opponents by any means necessary including Turbo Lasers, Boarding parties, alliances, and betrayal!

Every Game will create a different story of an epic space conflict with infinite replay ability!

—description from the designer
categories: Dice, Fighting, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Die Icon Resolution, Line of Sight, Moving Multiple Units, Team-Based Game, Worker Placement

name: Z-Engine
description:
Z-Engine / Z-エンジン is a racing game in which you modify your engine and customize your car during the race itself.

The game was included in Game Link vol. 6, a magazine released in December 2010, and it consists of a double-sided map, a single-sided map, counters, and rules.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: The Forgotten War
description:
The Forgotten War is a supplement for the popular Blitzkrieg Commander IV wargames rules, focussing on the Korean War from 1950-1953.

Written by Mark Fry and Rob Anderson, The Forgotten War contains 8 new army lists as well as 6 historical scenarios complete with maps. New rules include Line Commanders (for Wave Attacks), Street Barricades, Static Smoke Dischargers and Medical Bases.

A copy of Blitzkrieg Commander IV is needed to use this supplement.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Korean War, Wargame

name: Gêm Owain Glyndŵr
description: Gêm Owain Glyndŵr is a board game for 2-4 persons based on Owain Glyndŵr's revolt between 1400-1405. The board itself is based on a map of Wales during the period. The aim of the game is to travel around Wales visiting Welsh and English castles. It's a simple game, suitable for school, family and friends and also for Welsh learners.

name: Monsters and the Things That Destroy Them Double Pack
description:
[product contains the first two sets, The Dark and The Deep. Also contains bonus card from the recent Kickstarter.]

"It feels like a Love Letter version of Fantasy Realms! A great simple, quick, card game that provides a lot of fun." -Landon Squire, How Lou Sees It

Monsters is as portable and easy-to-learn as Love Letter and Coup. It features bluffing and strategic planning. Players with creativity and deductive reasoning will love it. There's multiple unique sets/cycles of the game, so once you know the rules for one set, you know the rules for all the sets. The game plays best with 2 or 3 players, but supports up to 4 players.

Incident 2: The Deep (mythic sea monsters)

Each Monster grants between 1 and 12 points at the end of the game, but watch out: most Tactical cards ("things") cancel 2 specific Monsters!
Your turn: Take a card into your hand from the pool of 4; if it's a monster, it wakes up, triggering its ability.
If you are over your hand limit of 3, discard face-down to your personal discard pile. (Peek at your discards at any time.)
When the deck is empty: Everyone discards down to 2 cards and compares their scores to determine the winner.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Deduction, Hand Management, Memory, Open Drafting

name: A Hard Day's Knight
description:
A Hard Day’s Knight is set in a fantasy medieval world. The player is able to select a knight from one of the four different territories and goes on an epic quest.

The game is played by moving your knight around a game board and visiting the four different territories. Each territory has unique monsters that the knight must defeat to obtain one of the four keys to the Valley of the Gods. Once a knight has required all four keys they may enter the Valley of the Gods to fight the Guardian. Only if the Guardian is defeated a player wins the game and becomes the supreme champion of the land.

To defeat a monster the Knight plays a Battle cards to perform an attack move. The attack moves range in difficulty, with more difficult attacks causing more damage to the Knight’s foe. To calculate if the attack move is successful the player rolls a D12 and if the number is equal or greater than the number on the battle card the knight hits their target. If a knight fails an attack roll, they are hit and will take damage. The knight will also collect gold, magical items and be able to level up abilities to aid them on their quest.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling

name: Bismarck's Breakout
description:
“Ship unmanoeuvrable. We shall fight to the last shell.”
– Vice-Admiral Günther Lütjens

This is a scenario for my ruleset There's The Effing Scheer, and its expansion Striking Effectively First, which allows you to wargame early- to mid-war WW2 naval combat.

I really enjoyed researching, writing and playtesting this scenario. And it is a very challenging scenario for the Kriegsmarine. On the face of it, the tiny German task force should have no chance against the sheer numbers of the Royal Navy.

But then a wargamer's inquisitiveness kicks in...
Did they need just one lucky hit to win that battle?
Could they have brushed past a pair of cruisers the day before to prevent being shadowed?
What if the Germans had tried a different route?
What if Holland had let the German task force slip past his capital ships while waiting for Tovey to come up?
What if that Catalina had never spotted Bismarck?
Or that torpedo hadn't jammed the rudder?
What if Bismarck had made it into range of its land-based air cover?
For such a sure thing of a scenario, there were a lot of variables.

The German mission to harry the British convoy routes in mid-1941 was always to be a perilous one, as the quote above illustrates. British intelligence, combined with the substantial strength of the Home Fleet, gave the Royal Navy all of the cards, yet Lütjens and his task force came surprisingly close to success. There are a fair few special rules for this scenario to represent not just the huge scope of this operation (at double the distance scale of my other scenarios) but also to capture the game of cat and mouse the two navies played for several days.

This scenario allows you to play as Tovey, aiming to bring the elusive German warships to heel as the net slowly tightens around them, shepherding your convoys to safety.
Or maybe you will play as Lütjens, hoping to repeat his earlier success in Operation Berlin by slipping past British task forces and wreaking havoc in the North Atlantic.
Just don't expect all your ships to make it back.

-description from the designer
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Pfui Spinne!
description:
The game board represents a pond that is divided into smaller and larger spaces. In the middle of the pond is a small raised plate as an island. The game includes spiders, frogs and flies. The spiders initially use the small island as a place to stay. The large spaces are intended for the frogs, while the spiders and flies are supposed to move on the small spaces. Outside the pond, on the edge, there are four crosses of yellow, green, red and blue colors. These positions are to be assigned to the frogs at the beginning of the game. The small green spaces on the banks of the pond are protective places; frogs cannot penetrate here. Up to four people can play, and each player receives a spider, a frog and four flies. Movement is determined by a die. The spiders may enter the game, when a fly of the same color reaches the space under the spider.
The frogs eat spiders and flies and the spiders eat frogs and flies. The last remaining player wins the game.

The rules include a version without a die.

The game was published about 1940.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Square Grid, Static Capture

name: The Right of Kings
description: The Right of Kings is a 2 to 4 player game inspired in the millennial struggle between realms to overpower one another in an endless campaign to find the rightful ruler. The purpose of the game is to reach the Oreka, the medallion of balance. Every round is a crusade where players thrive to assemble their court, build an army and unveil the right King before any other player.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Race

name: Risposte at the Eastern Solomons
description:
“In a dive-bombing attack, it’s not just a case of getting one plane or ten or even fifteen. You’ve got to get them all, you can’t afford to get hit.”
– Lieutenant Commander Elias B. Mott, Gunnery Officer for USS Enterprise

This is a scenario for my ruleset There's The Effing Scheer, and its expansion Striking Effectively First, which allows you to wargame early- to mid-war WW2 naval combat.

One of my favourite parts of wargaming are the what-ifs of history and how on the grand scale of things, so much seemingly comes down to luck. The best laid plans and all that. The Eastern Solomons struck me as an interesting engagement because both sides seemed to share an equal amount of luck, or at times a lack of it. It is almost like Coral Sea all over again.

The Americans start unlucky. They send a third of their carrier force away to refuel as their intelligence tells them they've got enough time until the Japanese offensive towards Guadalcanal will arrive. They are unlucky not to find the Japanese fleet carriers as the one accurate scout report is lost in the ether, and both of their strikes are wasted on secondary targets (though I'm sure the crew of Ryujo may feel differently). The Japanese were lucky enough to get the drop of the Americans, getting Shokaku and Zuikaku into strike range without being detected themselves, and getting the first punch in. American radar sends their CAP intercept up at the wrong altitude and the Japanese bombers attack. They strike first, but not effectively.

Then the luck seems to shift.
Enterprise is hit by three bombs and its steering locks in a circle as the second wave closes in, but then the second Japanese strike fails to find them. The strike from Rabaul turns back due to bad weather and Ryujo's strike fails to neutralise Henderson Field. Nagumo, feeling his work is done, pulls the carrier air cover back, allowing the Cactus Air Force to sink one of their precious transports and parry the invasion. Both sides pull back claiming victory. The Japanese held the field, but any tactical victory seemed phyrric and strategically the Americans still held Henderson Field.

As always, I've added a few special rules to bring this scenario to life, allowing you to step into the shoes of Nagumo and Fletcher as they duel for the third time in 1942. Will Henderson Field fall? Or will the Americans sink the last two carriers who struck Pearl Harbor less than a year before?

-description from the designer
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: The Indian Ocean Raid
description:
“The most dangerous moment of the war, and the one which caused me the greatest alarm, was when the Japanese fleet was heading for Ceylon and the naval base there. The capture of Ceylon, the consequent control of the Indian Ocean, and the possibility at the same time of a German conquest of Egypt would have closed the ring and the future would have been black.”

– Winston Churchill

This is a scenario for my ruleset There's The Effing Scheer, and its expansion Striking Effectively First, which allows you to wargame early- to mid-war WW2 naval combat.

I have been interested by the what-if nature of the Indian Ocean Raid of 1942 for some time. While researching Coral Sea and Midway for SEF, I was struck by the fact I knew so little about the British capital ship losses (a carrier and two heavy cruisers) just a few months before these two huge, better known clashes.
What had happened?
And how had the Kido Butai got out of it unscathed?

After the string of British defeats in the Pacific with Japan's entry to the war, the British were on the back foot. Enter the Eastern Fleet, a motley mix of WW1 battleships, modern aircraft carriers and a jumble of other vessels thrown together to block further Japanese expansion. But it never directly fought the Japanese carriers, instead Somerville chose the far more sensible option of keeping the fleet 'in being' so as to remain a long-term threat. But what if he'd gone another way?

This scenario allows you to play as Somerville, aiming to engage the veteran Kido Butai in favourable night conditions and finally shatter the brittle sword of the Japanese carrier fleet.
Or perhaps you will play as Nagumo, seeing if you can remove the Royal Navy thorn in your empire's side as it continues to expand in all directions?

-description from the designer
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Altar Card Game
description:
Altar is a card game where two players face off using a 40-card deck selected from an online database. Each deck can contain up to 3 copies of the same card, unless specified otherwise.

In Altar, each player embodies an Infanteer, a being capable of materializing the energy of the Dream Plane in the real world through Altars, powerful machines of unknown technology created by a forgotten civilization. The Dreams (represented by cards) generated by the Infanteers belong to one of six different Pulses: Order, Chaos, Truth, Lies, Life, and Death. The Pulses can be seen as fundamental ways of understanding the surrounding world. Each Pulse has its own identity and primary strategy to win a game. Truth seeks to triumph through cooperation and territorial control; Chaos is willing to sacrifice its own forces to lead to the opponent's loss; Death manipulates the flow of life to destroy the opponent's resources; Life is a quiet force that focuses on strengthening its allies; Lies uses trickery and traps to gain the upper hand; Order loves... to maintain order at any cost. A deck can contain cards from any number of Pulses.

One after the other during their turn, each player places cards from their hand on the field and activates their abilities to eliminate cards from the opponent's deck. A player automatically loses the game as soon as their deck no longer contains any cards.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deck Construction, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Which Craft?: Grave Danger
description:
The Grave Danger expansion introduces the threat of an undead minion, and the fun of charades to the Which Craft? hidden role game.
Unearth a whole new level of fun with 4 new characters, a new action card, and a cursed item card!
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game
mechanics: Acting, Hidden Roles, Set Collection, Team-Based Game, Voting

name: Campus Paths
description:
Campus Paths is a strategic simulation of university life. Players take on the role of students, juggling academics, social life, work, and wellness, while acquiring skills and filling their curriculum vitae with experiences as they prepare for their careers after graduation. A collaboration between Resolve, an applied game design research group at UNB and UNB's Career Development and Employment Centre, the game was designed by Scott Preston with consultation from career counsellor Nat Perry (M.Ed., C.C.C.).

The game takes place over four rounds (one for each year of a typical undergraduate degree). Players take turns drawing from a deck of action cards and choosing one to play. How many they draw depends on their current wellness level. The cards depict activities that a typical undergraduate student might do in college (join a student club, meet with their academic advisor, run for student council, etc.) Their choices impact four key areas (academics, wellness, curriculum vitae, and cash flow), all of which are tracked on a player sheet. At the end of each round, players may receive scholarships or summer jobs, depending the strength of the academics or the C.V. Then they pay for the next year's tuition and another round begins.

Included is a Facilitator’s Guide that contains suggestions for how to run a session and tips for generating a productive post-game discussion.

—description from the designer
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Set Collection, Simulation

name: The Scotland Card Game
description:
The game is composed of two decks of cards: one deck of sixty Action cards and one of forty Location cards. Each Location card has three of five possible symbols: Valour, Strength, Courage, Wisdom, or Spirit. Each Action Card has two random symbols on it. The deck of Location Cards is placed face down in the center of the table and the top three cards from it are laid face-up in a row. This is called the ‘Display’. The Action deck is placed face down nearby as a draw pile and the top card is turned face-up beside it to start the Discard pile.

Each player is dealt three Location Cards, which they place in a row face-up in front of them. This is their ‘Array’. The player is then dealt three Action Cards, which they keep hidden as part of their hand. At the start of their turn, each player either draws the top card from the Action deck or takes the top card from the face-up Discard pile, unless it is a Special card. Players may now do one of three things: 1) Play an Action Card from their hand to match one of the symbols on any of the Location Cards in their Array, or play a Special Action card from their hand and follow the instruction text; or 2) Re-arrange Action Cards which are already matched to Location Cards; or 3) Discard all your Action or Location Cards and draw three new ones. The player’s turn has now ended.

At the end of their turn, the player must have three Location Cards in their Array, and three Action Cards in their hand. They must draw or discard as necessary, and also make sure there is at least one face-up card in the Action discard pile. If the Action Card deck runs out, the discard pile is turned over to form the new one, then the top card is turned face-up to form the new discard pile.

When all three symbols on one of a player’s Location Cards have been matched, the player declares it ‘Completed’ and places it face-down in their ‘Completion Pile’. They then draw a new Location Card from the Display and add it to their Array, and turn up a new card and add it to the Display. When a player has completed six Location Cards, they are the winner, unless the players agree beforehand to play to eight.

name: Tokyo Horror
description:
This was an expansion that set the conflict in the city of Tokyo. The map was inside the magazine TACTICS no. 58 (September 1988). Instructions were on the back of the map.

The Japanese Arkham Horror game had the extra counters necessary to play this.

name: The Game of Clock
description:
The Game of Clock is a rather obscure Australian game that was meant to entertain and also teach children about the time. It is essentially a race game using a spinner and moving the hands of the clock

The game board has two clock faces with brass hands. Underneath each clock is a spinner with 3 inner circles of numbers. A player spins the spinner, then adds the numbers to give a count that moves the minute hand on their clock face.

The length of the game is predetermined before starting. i.e From 12 O'Clock to 3 O'Clock or 180 minutes. The winner is the first to reach the set time.

The game also provides facts about time, seasons (Southern Hemisphere), and celestial movements.

name: Rex Britannorum
description:
In 55 and 54 BC, Julius Caesar landed in the south of the island of Britain, then known as Britannia. This was the first contact between Rome and the various British kingdoms. Numerous kings rallied to Caesar to survive, or to benefit from Rome's protection against the hostility of other British tribes: these were the first client kingdoms. This system would develop over the next century, so that by the time of Claudius' Roman invasion in AD 43, many client kingdoms were already well established.

Among these were the Regnenses, Brigantes and Iceni, who fought mercilessly for power. With Rome's support, they all tried to obtain the title of King of the British, in Latin: REX BRITANNORUM.

Rex Britannorum is a strategy game that can be played solo, with 2 or 3 players. Victory is achieved by occupying roads and cities in the different regions of Britannia displayed on the game board. Moreover, each player will have two personal objectives to complete, which will earn them additional victory points.

Commit your troops in the right place and at the right time to outplay your opponents. Resolution of battles is not random, so use your sense of strategy wisely to become the Rex Britannorum.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Connections, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Murder Party: Sherlock Holmes
description: Liven up a party with friends with this murder mystery party game that will take you casually through an evening or even a whole weekend! A crime has been committed in the peaceful town of Bumble Town, where the famous Sherlock Holmes spends his retirement. To get to the bottom of the crime, you should collect as many clues as possible. But you can only get them from your fellow players by enticing them to do certain secret tasks for you!

name: BattleTech: Adventures – Ghosts of Obeedah
description:
BattleTech Adventures: Ghosts of Obeedah takes players into a dangerous hunt for one of the last great secrets of the Jihad. From ground zero of a lethal pandemic to the wreckage of long-fallen societies, join the search between the “safer” havens of a universe at war, and find out what happened to the fanatical monsters whose deadly legacy still haunts the Inner Sphere to this very day. This adventure includes biographies on several key personalities, special rules, and adventure Tracks designed for use with BattleTech, A Time of War: The BattleTech Role-Playing Game, A Time of War Companion, and MechWarrior: Destiny, as well as data and record sheets for key worlds, units, and non-player characters unique to this story.

—description from publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction

name: The Football Game.co
description:
Crowdfunded football card game that tests your knowledge against the clock.

Draw a card for the subject (i.e. players who have won the world cup) then draw a rime card (30 seconds). Players then 'bid' in increments for their knowledge ('I can name 6') until challenged by an opponent. If the player successfuly meets their total within the time, they win the point. If they fail, the challenger takes the point instead.

name: Rap Battles: The Hip-Hop Rhyming Word Game for Wannabe MCs
description:
Mad Libs meets Method Man, Missy Elliot, and more with this hilarious word game to test rhyme skills, pun abilities and quick wits. It’s the perfect gift for all hip-hop fans, aspiring MCs and street poets.

Channel your inner MC with this quick-fire word game designed to test your rhyme skills against family and friends, settling once and for all who is the greatest rapper.

Fast, furious, hilariously funny, and endlessly playable, Rap Battles is the essential card game for any aspiring MCs, wordsmiths and hip-hop fans, playable with up to 6 individuals or groups. The challenge: to come up with that killer burn, pun or rhyme to leave your opponent without a come back, in stitches, or both.

—description from the publisher

name: Dealing Blows
description:
Over 3 rounds, players will face off in this light strategy card fighting game. Determining their strategy for the fight, they will take a limited number of cards from their match strategy (deck) into each round. Revealing cards simultaneously one at a time each player will endeavour to land heavy hits on their opponent whilst blocking anticipated incoming hits. Bonuses can be gained by stringing together combos of cards, but is that what your opponent is trying to do or are they bluffing, hoping you will try to block while opening yourself up to taking extra damage from a different attack?

At the end of each round players return to their corners to be sponged down & discuss new tactics. Two cards used in the previous round are discarded from the game and a new hand built from the remaining cards in their deck before the fighters square off again. Get knocked to the canvas and you will need to roll the knockdown dice to see if you recover and regain your feet before the 10 count is reached. It gets progressively harder to stand after each knockdown, and hitting the canvas for a fourth time means you have lost on a TKO.

Easy to learn & quick to teach. New players will be off & fighting each other in no time, & the more they play the more they'll begin second guessing their opponent, acting out the moves, & talking in an 'announcer' voice.

So will you be the heavyweight champion or are you nothing but a lightweight?

—description from the designer
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deck Construction, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Smazzi & Scazzi
description:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/smazziescazzi/smazziand...
>>> LIVE ON KICKSTARTER NOW! <<<

Roll a 365 dice and draw an ordinary day. You are having a beer with your gang of friends in the little village bar. In that little hole of a world, even the little grandson who comes in to get sweets for his grandmother has a history of mischief as thick as the sole of a Buffalo. You are playing trumps and the only winner is boredom, but suddenly (the) Noodle(s)? Tagliatella - your brother's friend - comes in, and with him the mathematical breakthrough! You're already up on your feet, about to shout "Yo bro'!" when that ridiculous ringtone for your aunt goes off from your smartphone at a criminal volume. 
"HI DEAR, IT'S GRANDMA(AUNTY?! GO AND GET ME SOME CREAM FOR SORES AT THE CHEMIST'S, I'M ALL STUCK…"

Smazzi & Scazzi is an alternative to pick up and deliver games, a gateway with ruthless overturns and comically irreverent overtones, set in the worst squares of suburban towns where a micro-world of crazy characters with borderline habits live in captivity. Each player has errands to get out of the way before they can return to the bar as the winner. In order to do away with the errands, they can either actually run them or pawn them off on another player!
Each errand (described by the TROUBLE (DODGE) cards) is a piece in a mosaic of interwoven stories. Each character who gives you assignments will have something to tell, short stories of escape from everyday life, great adventures or petty crimes; recipes of dubious taste, but also indestructible book odysseys. A game within a game or a comic within a game, which you can discover game by game or flick through card by card.
 
To add even more spice to the matter, there is the contribution of an exceptional illustrator, the one and only person capable of giving volume to this human circus, Enrico Macchiavello, a Genoese artist with an immediately recognisable style, author of numerous works that for years have filled the happiest memories of all Italians (among the most important we recall the magnificent animations for the Ceres adverts, Skifidol, the album covers for Meganoids and Fragments, the comic 'Little Boy Goes to Hell’ and the more recent Zoombi). If you too want to do as the Italian General Investigations & Special Operations Police Division and follow him, you would do very well!

—description from the designer
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Humor, Party Game
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Northerners
description:
In the newly discovered island of Westfoldir, four jarls seek to establish their dominance in a new territory. Driven from their previous homes by storms and barren lands, they aim to rise as the supreme ruler in these more promising regions. Yet, the gods, or the Aesir, keep a close watch, occasionally intervening in mortal affairs to either reward or punish. The jarls need to not only build their villages and clans but also gain the favor of the gods through gifts and offerings. A legendary figure, the spirit shaman, also plays a pivotal role. Rumored to be in the eternal favor of the Aesir, the clan that finds the shaman first will have a distinct advantage.

The game is a strategy board game with resource management, worker placement, land exploration, and divine intervention mechanics as it's primary mechanics.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Movement, Hand Management, Stock Holding, Worker Placement

name: war, War? WAR!!
description:
In war, War? WAR!! Choose to lead 1 of 4 warring factions determined on conquering the lands of Elohssa, destroy and outwit your enemies by simply playing the highest card, easy... right?

Players choose between 4 mighty factions each with their own unique characters and land abilities and assemble their hand of army and royalty cards. By simply playing 1 card face-down and revealing simultaneously, the strongest value card survives and scores victory skulls - the lowest value is also rewarded with a powerful seal. These seals allow players to sneak a look at other cards before they reveal, swap cards, increase and decrease the strength of any card to name a few.

war, War? WAR!! What is it good for? Absolutely fun!! Pick up and play, a quick 2 to 4 player travel sized game with more meat on it's bones than first meets the eye.

—description from the publisher

name: The Dark Forest
description:
Attention, brave souls, for you are about to enter the realm of darkness and enigma - "Dark Forest." This board game will immerse you in the depths of despair and secrets, in a place where no glimmer of light has ever penetrated.

The outside world has vanished, the village is no more, and hope has dwindled. You must step into the abyss of this ominous forest and unveil its horrifying mysteries. Four brave individuals, each with their own dark pasts, find themselves brought together in a chilling tavern. They don't know if they are chosen or mere pawns in this grim game of destiny.

Among them, an old mage who reminisces his ancient secrets in the darkness. A former professor of the College of Mages, whose insatiable thirst for knowledge has left only a bitter void. A warrior who has recently returned from a bloody conflict, his soul scarred by battle for the king. A young huntress, trading carcasses and bringing them to the local tavern, where she has found her refuge. The tavern keeper, a former herbalist, whose connection to this place is as mysterious as the Dark Forest itself.

In the Dark Forest, every turn is a step into the abyss, where darkness clouds the mind, and only chance can shed light on the path. Players explore locations, revealing cards that may hold treasures or horrors on their reverse sides. They might stumble upon quests, where choices will determine who remains in darkness and who attempts to unravel the bleak mysteries.

The game is steeped in darkness and tension, where every decision is a choice between life and death, between discovering the truth and delving deeper into a chasm of lies and secrets. In The Dark Forest, your soul is at stake, and only the bravest will emerge from it alive, undeniably changed.

—description from the designer

name: Quiz d'Or
description:
This is the football board game you have been waiting for! Challenge your football knowledge, gather your friends and family, form teams, and prepare for a game that will bring joy and knowledge.

Quiz d’Or is a tailored experience for football fans of all knowledge levels. Dive into the rich history and beauty of the game, as you navigate trivia questions and choose the right strategy to beat your opponents.

If you’re a fan of the sport , this game promises to ignite your passion for the beautiful game and keep you entertained for hours

Quiz d’Or promises an engaging experience, it's a celebration of the game that brings people together, fostering camaraderie and building lasting memories.

—description from the publisher

name: Lairs
description:
You’ve worked hard to earn your spot in the Adventurers Guild, but one last obstacle remains. You must square off with a cunning rival guild hopeful in an exam of precarious paths that will test your skills at building a devious dungeon...and exploring one. To pass, you have to complete the tricky labyrinth your opponent has created full of dead ends, traps, enchanted monsters — oh, and if you can find it, valuable treasures. You enter their dungeon with your own set of skills and over the course of this challenge, you'll grow as an adventurer. Will it be enough to map the right path, defeat the monsters in your way, and escape with the most valuable collection of treasure? Your spot in the Adventurers Guild depends on it!

Lairs is a two-player game for ages 10 and up that plays in about 35 minutes. Players begin with a set of walls, traps, treasures, and monsters, then use them to create a challenging catacomb for their opponent to explore while at the same time attempting to navigate their opponent's dungeon using guile, deduction, and a little bit of luck. The stakes are high! Only one player can make it into the Guild!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Deduction, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement

name: Dystopian Wars: Fortune and Glory – 2 Player Starter Set
description:
The Great Powers vie for control of the world's trade routes, unleashing mercenary forces to disrupt shipping and sow chaos and confusion to destabilise their rivals. Two of the most notable of these privateers are The Crimson League and The Honorable Eclipse Company.

The Crimson League is led by Princess Scheherazade. Escaping the traditions of her royal family, she joined the Covenant of the Enlightened only to leave when the Egalitarian and Custodians schism came to the fore. Now, she operates following her own unknowable plan. Angry at the power of the Order within the Sultanate, she lashes out, taking contracts that appear to have nothing to do with the religious zealots, only for some to realise later that there was design all along.

The Honorable Eclipse Company have secured lucrative escort contracts with significant clients around the globe. The HEC offer security and defence solutions to those who cannot apply direct political or military action in safeguarding their investments. The HEC have had major investment from the Union of Federated States and often that Great Power has used the Company when the deployment or involvement of a Union battlefleet may be politically unwise. Though some might call the involvement of the HEC an unwelcome influence by the Union in global affairs, in truth, many commanders have found that their need for support in a theatre of engagement can only be solved by hiring the Honorable Eclipse Company.

Fortune and Glory contains two mercenary battlefleets that can be used with any Faction making this box set a must-buy for any Dystopian Wars player. Add additional airpower to your existing forces, but make sure you pay them or you could be their next contract!

Contents:

1x Excelsior Class Heavy Aircruiser. (May also be built as Venture or Custodian Class)
3x Steward Class Sentry Airships. (May also be built as Constellation, Republic, Ticonderoga or Ranger Class)
5x Bogota Class Carryall
5x Union SRS Tokens
1x Lyceum Aerial Dreadnought
3x Nasr Class Skyship. (May also be built as Awsbiri or Muharib Class)
3x Hirka Class Skycutter
3x Alsaqr Class Skybarque
3 x Sultanate SRS Tokens
2x Titan Class Heavy Conveyer. (May be built as Passenger, Freight or Oil Variants)
2x Merchant Ships
2x Escort
2x Small Ship Tokens
2x Ground Assault Detachment Tokens

-description from publisher's website
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Dragon Dell
description:
Dragon Dell is a fantasy themed strategy card game where players compete to be the first to establish a small village in a land teeming with hostile dragons. Players will face off waves of wild Dragons (and possibly dragons sent by other players), as they fight to grow their village.

The game is played over a series of rounds, which feature simultaneous play. During a round, players will draw magical Orbs and combine some into stronger Orbs. All players then do the same with dragons (draw dragons and breed some into stronger dragons). Next, players will utilize command cards to decide in secret if they will go into battle and what their dragons will do (help them in battle, or go attack other players). All commands are then revealed at the same time.

Finally, all players who chose to go to battle will do so, each fighting their own battle. They will utilize the orbs and dragons they gathered earlier, along with their characters' special abilities, to fight off the wave of dragons attacking them (along with dragons sent by other players).

Each player who wins their battle will gain a new character in their village, but will also face a larger wave of Dragons in the next battle. The first player to get six characters and defeat the sixth wave is the winner.

—description from the designer

name: Chase
description:
Chase is a creative strategy game played on a chess board where players restrict the movement of their opponent in order to trap them and win the game. They must be careful, however, not to trap themselves in the process.

The objective of Chase is to jump, block, and taunt your opponent, and collect fees, so that their pawn(s) no longer have freedom of movement.

The game ends when an opponent has no more legal moves remaining, allowing the other player to win the game.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Maze, Print & Play, Territory Building
mechanics: Action Retrieval, Area Movement, Chaining, Connections, Enclosure, Grid Coverage, Grid Movement, Move Through Deck, Pattern Movement, Pieces as Map, Point to Point Movement, Square Grid, Tile Placement, Zone of Control

name: Qo
description:
Qo is a 'creative strategy' game played on a game board with an 8x8 grid where players remove the lodestones of their opponent to keep the game in balance. It uses the new DiCe game mechanic where every move you make also benefits your opponent (and every move you make against them can also work against you).

Qo can be considered a di-centralized version of Go, though with necessarily different rules and gameplay.

The objective of Qo is to keep the game in balance by removing blocked lodestones until the game ends. The game ends when either opponent runs out of lodestones or when either opponent has formed a complete horizontal or vertical line with their lodestones.

Qo has just 3 simple rules. Yet, during gameplay a paradox of elegance forms when players realize the beauty of what is happening on the board. See if you can figure out how it works.

1800 is a Japanese doujin (Fan-made) game that was only available at Japanese game shows, such as the Tokyo Game Market. It was made on demand, and you had to order one in advance and pick it up at the show. These were not available to the general public, and in most cases, the show was the only place where the game could be obtained.

1800 is a game of exploration and conquest in the Industrial Age. The players become monarchs and spread their influence around the world, building colonies, and waging wars of conquest in order to become the dominant power.

Here is a description from the designer's web page:

This card game is set in the colonial era from the 16th to the 18th century, and players take on the role of becoming the great powers of the time. This is a game where you compete to acquire private land cards. If you can't get a colony card, collect force cards and take a neighboring country's colony. Build up a large colonial empire by the end of the game by using diplomacy cards, avoiding wars, and leasing colonies.

Recently an expansion, that added Denmark and Sweden, was added to the game.

The game requires assembly.

—user summary

name: Sieg Zion
description:
This is the first part of the Gundam RPG game by Tsukuda. It introduced Space Warfare.

It includes rulebook, scenario book, two unpunched counter sheets, two mounted maps, two player aids, and 30 data cards,

It can be played on its own and does not require any other games in this series. Further sets enhance the experience and add things like land warfare and colony battles.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Twilight of Zion
description:
This is the third game in the Tsukuda Gundam RPG series. Each game in the series adds a new aspect to the gameplay. This volume adds additional rules, such as hand-held firearms, and more scenarios.

It includes rulebook, scenario book, one unpunched counter sheets, one mounted map, two dice, two sets of unpunched data cards (60 total), two player aids.

It can be played on its own and does not require any other games in this series. Further sets enhance the experience and add things like land warfare and colony battles.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: DUCK YOU!
description: This is a fun and easy tower stacking party game. The player (ducker) has to place game pieces (ducklings) on the tower. When there are at least 3 pieces on the tower, the player can start playing joker ducklings. A joker duckling makes one player either play 3 game pieces or a joker card. When a player topples over the tower, everyone else yells "Duck you!" to their face. The player then picks up all the pieces, and the game continues from that player. If you are the first one to get rid of all your game pieces, you win!

name: Malware Mayhem Hacker Duel: Cyber War Edition
description:
Malware Mayhem Hacker Duel is a two-player face-off using a tower-defense style game must defend their high, medium and low value data which is placed into one of three systems. Each player also has one secret that can be moved between the systems as long as the data is still intact. The objective of the game is to capture the secret.

Each player builds cyberweapons including a botnet, trojans, and zero-day exploits that can be used to attack the opponent's systems. Each system can be defended by firewalls, anti-virus and intrusion detection systems. An attack consists of three phases: breaching the network perimeter, hacking the system, and then in a later turn attempting to capture the data and secrets.

Each hacker is assisted by an Agent who helps raise funds, restores disabled cyberweapons and defenses, or uses one of their unique special abilities (each agent has two) such as sending spam or initiating ransomware. Each hacker can employ up to two agents by hiring or firing from the pool of available agents.

The currency of the game is cryptocoins. The DarkWeb Marketplace allows weapons and defenses to be bought and stolen data to be sold.

The game includes two decks of cards which are used to collect resources and to perform special actions (or enhanced actions).

Malware Mayhem Hacker Duel, Cyber War Edition features a hacker duel between the White Hat supported by the Hactivist agent and Black Hat hacker who is supported by the Scammer agent. Additional agents included in this set are the Freelancer and the Script Kiddie.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling, Tech Trees / Tech Tracks, Turn Order: Role Order

name: Malware Mayhem Hacker Duel: State Actor Edition
description:
Malware Mayhem Hacker Duel is a two-player face-off using a tower-defense style game must defend their high, medium and low value data which is placed into one of three systems. Each player also has one secret that can be moved between the systems as long as the data is still intact. The objective of the game is to capture the secret.

Each player builds cyberweapons including a botnet, trojans, and zero-day exploits that can be used to attack the opponent's systems. Each system can be defended by firewalls, anti-virus and intrusion detection systems. An attack consists of three phases: breaching the network perimeter, hacking the system, and then in a later turn attempting to capture the data and secrets.

Each hacker is assisted by an Agent who helps raise funds, restores disabled cyberweapons and defenses, or uses one of their unique special abilities (each agent has two) such as sending spam or initiating ransomware. Each hacker can employ up to two agents by hiring or firing from the pool of available agents.

The currency of the game is cryptocoins. The DarkWeb Marketplace allows weapons and defenses to be bought and stolen data to be sold.

The game includes two decks of cards which are used to collect resources and to perform special actions (or enhanced actions).

Malware Mayhem Hacker Duel, State Actor Edition brings geo-politics into the equation featuring a hacker duel between the Superpower hacker supported by the Deputy agent and the Rogue State hacker who is supported by the Threat Actor agent. Additional agents included in this set are the Spy and the Cyberterrorist.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling, Tech Trees / Tech Tracks, Turn Order: Role Order

name: Arcana Towers
description:
Arcana Towers is a Tarot-themed board game set in a fantasy realm of Four Kingdoms. It revolves around all the cards found in a Tarot deck. The deck is split into two: the Minor Arcana and the Major Arcana.

The first goal is to collect face cards (Royalty Cards) from the Minor Arcana (which functions like a deck 56 playing cards) in order to collect stones (coin pieces) and draw from the smaller deck of 22 Major Arcana cards.

The overall objective is to win the game by collecting 11 towers which are denoted on a player's black die and red die. You gain towers a few different ways: by collecting 11 stones of a single colour, by collecting 3 Royalty Cards in a single Court on your board, or finally by the effects of Major Arcana Cards that typically grant stones or towers. All of your turn options are marked on a player's Turn Actions tile. There is an Opening Action, Main Action (4 choices) and an Elemental Action (fuelled by a unique Elemental ability and cards). Specialty Cards may also be played before any of these Actions.

Players take turn after turn until one of two things happens: 1: someone reaches 11 Towers, or, 2: the Major Arcana Deck runs out of (22) cards, (if the deck runs out one last turn is taken, and the player with the most Towers and Stones wins the game!

-description from designer
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Turn Order: Claim Action

name: Árnyékmókus
description:
Chloe and her friends went for a hike in the forest. They loved the squirrels jumping around from tree to tree. On the way home, they got extremely tired. It would be amazing right now to turn into a squirrel and just leap home! To make time pass more quickly, they headed home by jumping on the shadows of trees and fences, just like squirrels. Help them find the correct shadows, so they can get home!

In this game the players get cards with pictures on them. The pictures are built of 2 or 3 shapes. In each turn you have 30 seconds to reach into the bag and try to feel the correct shapes that are on your cards. Build the shadows of your cards with the shapes you draw from the bag. The player who completes all their cards first wins the game.
The game has a cooperative mode and 2 easy variations for smaller children.

name: Pizsamaparti Babarókánál
description:
There’s a giant sleepover at Baby Fox’s: the whole kindergarten is invited, and everyone brought their friends too. Mother Fox put down big mats in Baby Fox’s room, and made the bed for the cubs, everyone changed into their pyjamas. But no one actually wanted to sleep! Instead, they hid under the blankets. Help Mother Fox find where everyone’s hidden, and put them all to sleep!

In this game there are cards with baby animals in their pyjamas. You find tiles showing only a part of the animal cards because when they are hiding you only see an ear, a leg of a tail from them. You randomly draw 9 tiles and create 3 groups of 3 tiles from them. You have one minute to memorize each tile then you have to cover the tiles with the 3 little blankets. Shuffle the animal deck and in each turn you have two options:
1. Draw a card and if you think you saw that baby animal hiding under one of the blankets you take the card and it’s the end of your turn. If you think the animal isn’t hiding you can check the next card and decide to take it or leave it. Eighter way your turn is over and the next player comes.
2. If you think you forgot which animals are hiding you can choose to peek under one of the three blankets and refresh your memories.
When the deck is empty you reveal the baby animals under the blankets and collect points if you remembered correctly. You can play many rounds and compare your scores at the end.
The game has a cooperative version and variations for smaller and bigger children.

name: Dot Duel
description:
Dot Duel is a fast-paced, card-collection game where players race to find the number represented on the rolled dice. Speed is rewarded, but players must be careful not to misfire or they may find themselves in a high-stakes duel that might make or break their chances of winning!

The game is relatively simple. Included are a pair of dice and the Dot Duel Deck - 57 cards, each different from the other. Every card has 8 symbols representing a number 2-12 on it, and there may be more than one symbol representing the same number on a single card (though no symbol will be exactly the same on the same card). Every pair of cards has EXACTLY one matching symbol between the cards.

A turn starts with a roll of the dice and six of the cards face up in between all players. Then all players race to find and accurately count the number of matching symbols to the rolled number on a card, making a claim for the card once they’re confident they are correct. Opponents check their claims, and can initiate a duel if they are incorrect. Claim a Double Dot, when two of the showing cards show an exactly matching symbol of the rolled number, and claim all six cards at once. Play ends when all cards are collected and victory is claimed by the player with the most cards.

Duels are an integral part of the game. In them, players put up cards from their collection in a one-on-one face off where they must race to correctly count the matching symbols among all the showing cards. Winner steals cards from their opponent, and a Double Dot allows you to steal their entire deck!

There are other variations of gameplay for beginners and younger players that promote fun for any audience.

-description from designer

name: Próba Ognia: Draught
description:
Second expansion to Próba Ognia. It introduces new Locations, new Scenario, new cards for Firefighters, sparks and conflagration.

This time Firefighters have to protect fields around the city. Once there is a spark on each of them, they immediately lose. The Element player cannot move the Element tokens, but have many cards with effects allowing to swap sparks with fire or conflagration. Moreover this expansion introduces a Wind mechanism - most of the Element cards refer to the direction of the Wind, making its actions more predictable, yet dangerous.

It was released during Próba Ognia Championship 2023.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck Construction, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Variable Phase Order

name: Railway Clash
description:
Compete to become the most successful luxury railway owner! To win, you must be part railway operator and part saboteur, using fiendish tactics to delay or destroy rival railways. In the luxury railway wars, there is only one rule:  No mercy!

Summary

Build the longest and most profitable train. Sabotage your opponents as they try to do the same.  Earn revenue by coupling (making card combos) to yield higher profits while taking advantage of Sabotage cards and station modifiers. End-of-game bonuses for five category cars and longest trains. Some cars have mini-games (like slots in the casino or the comedy clubs).

Nail-biting Finishes

Constant creation and destruction/modification of trains as players compete means it’s difficult for one player to get too far ahead. This creates a natural balance where every player can compete to the end. There's always a chance for a dramatic underdog victory.

Object of the Game

Reach the end of the luxury train tour with the most money.
mechanics: Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Drawing, Income, Interrupts

name: Nedca: Journey to the North
description:
Welcome, brave Survivor, to the dawn of a new era in the majestic Land of Bendada. A cataclysmic earthquake has shattered the land and the once-mighty ruling House of Jo'orka Hanzy had fallen, where the legendary Nedca City of Abanda now lies in ruins. From the ashes of destruction, five elite Houses have emerged, their destinies intertwined in an epic struggle for dominion over this newborn world. Will you seize this extraordinary opportunity to erect a new Nedca City and etch your name into the annals of Bendada's history?

As the visionary architect of your House's fate, you shall navigate a treacherous landscape of strategic choices, where every decision holds profound consequences. Will you channel the depths of your brilliance to construct awe-inspiring structures that stand as testaments to your unconquerable will? Or shall you embark on a daring quest to unlock the secrets of technological marvels, harnessing their boundless power to surpass all rivals in sheer ingenuity? then again, you may embrace the call of battle, brandishing your weapons with unmatched prowess and crushing your adversaries beneath your unwavering might.

Victory, dear Survivor, lies within your grasp. Ascend to greatness by raising your Influence, forging unbreakable Bonds, vanquishing all foes who dare to defy you, completing legendary quests that will echo through eternity, or delving into the profound mysteries of the five sacred Gems of Bendada. Within these intertwined paths to glory, your imagination knows no bounds, and the destiny of your House shall be shaped by the boundlessness of your dreams.

Embrace this unparalleled opportunity to rebuild a shattered world, to sculpt a new Nedca City that will stand as a testament to your unwavering spirit, and to etch your name in letters of fire across the grand tapestry of Bendada's history. The time has come, Survivor, to seize your rightful place among the legends of this epic saga.

—description from the designer
categories: City Building, Civilization, Fantasy, Medieval, Negotiation, Territory Building
mechanics: Alliances, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Hexagon Grid, Income, Modular Board, Negotiation, Once-Per-Game Abilities, Player Elimination, Turn Order: Random, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up, Victory Points as a Resource

name: The Amazing Slinky Game
description:
This is a unique Slinky game based off of the different tricks you can do with a Slinky. It does use a game board that you move your pawns around after a trick is performed. You spin the wheel and then have to perform the trick. If successful, you then move your pawn piece based on the number that is given for that trick. The game came with an actual Slinky!

It has a basic Start and finish line with 22 sections in the pathway. The respective tricks and their points are listed here.

Slinky Catch -1
Slinky Golf -1
Slinky Roll -2
Slinky Steps -2
Slinky Slide -3
Slinky Flip -3

—user summary

name: Pick-Up Chips
description:
Although this game is similar to Pick-Up Sticks, it takes it to a different level because you are picking up plastic potato chips. Each chip is numbered and also has one of the 4 suits on it.

You shake up the chips (Very reminiscent of a Pringles can and shape chip!) Letting them fall on the table top. You take a short plastic colored stick and carefully pick up the potato chip you think you can remove and place it 12" past the pile in front of you. You can tap on a chip to turn it over.

There are variations of the game, based on the suit of the car and number pictured on the chips. There are 4 game options to pick from before you begin playing.

—user summary

name: Hunter, Gatherer
description:
Welcome to Hunter Gatherer. In this game for 1 to 4 players, you must work cooperatively to explore a variety of dangerous post apocalyptic locations, gathering resources while being hunted by zombies.

Your team of (up to) 4 characters will find weapons and equipment to boost their chances of survival. If they survive long enough, they will develop skills that will turn them into seasoned survivors of the wastelands.

Hunter Gatherer is a miniature agnostic game. It relies on you to supply the miniatures and terrain for the scenarios and rules contained within. Blank sheets are included for you to write your own scenarios.

—description from the designer
categories: Exploration, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Zombies
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing

name: Wastelands Highway
description:
Welcome to Wasteland Highway. In this game for 1 to 4 players, you must work cooperatively to explore and survive the open wastes of a post apocalyptic world.

Wasteland Highway is a miniature agnostic game. It relies on you to supply the miniatures and terrain for the scenarios and rules contained within. Blank sheets are included for you to write your own scenarios. Players of Gaslands will be ready to go!

While “Matchbox / Hot Wheels” scale was used to play test this game, any scale you have will work just as well. Your terrain can be 3D or a flat board… it doesn’t matter. You can even use paper and tokens.

—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, Exploration, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing

name: Texas & Pacific: Refrigerator Cars Expansion
description: The Texas & Pacific: Refrigerator Cars Expansion provides a benefit for track in Agricultural lands.
categories: American West, Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Trains
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Hexagon Grid, Income, Network and Route Building, Stock Holding

name: Texas & Pacific: Railroad Yard Expansion
description: The Texas & Pacific: Railroad Yard Expansion provides a benefit for Cities.
categories: American West, Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Trains
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Hexagon Grid, Income, Network and Route Building, Stock Holding

name: Texas & Pacific: Mergers Expansion
description: The Texas & Pacific: Mergers Expansion provides a mechanism for merging two railroads into one.
categories: American West, Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Trains
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Hexagon Grid, Income, Network and Route Building, Stock Holding

name: Saturday Showdown: College Football C&D
description: Saturday Showdown is the latest College Football Card & Dice game, bringing the best of Saturdays to your tabletop! A C&D game created by NBT Sports Games, it takes real-life stats and using team sheets and charts, allows for simple college football game play! This game uses just 5 D20 dice, and a single game can be completed in 45-60 minutes.

name: Alchemy!: The Ether Expansion
description:
Available through the Kickstarter campaign and also later via Print & Play.

Contains:
33 x Potions
42 x Action/Equipment Cards
15 x Components
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Elmo's Circus
description:
This gams is for ages 3+ and 2-4 players. It is made up of a long game board that has different cut-out standees of a snack bar, elephant and other circus related themes. The game is to help learn and count in a fun coordinated circus theme path game. Elmo is the ringmaster, spin the spinner and move along the path. The first player to get through the 3 archways to join Elmo is the winner.

There are 4 Sesame Street Characters
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: First XI Cricket
description: First XI Cricket is an exciting, cricket-themed card game for all ages. It includes 96 player cards featuring all the legends of the game from across 8 countries. The game uses real test match statistics as well as an assortment of action cards, like the Yorker, Jaffa, Streaker, Hat-trick, Double Hat-trick, Block, Butterfingers, Follow-on, Match-up, Trade and Wild Card.

name: 魔法少女ヴァーサス (Mahoushoujo Versus)
description:
魔法少女ヴァーサス (Mahoushoujo Versus) is a two player fighting game from Japan.

A team is formed by four magical girls. Three of them form a formation and start the battle! Defender, Attacker, Supporter. Master 3 different positions!

If even one person on the opposing team reduces their life to 0, you win! Even if you lose due to damage, there is always a comeback!

You become a 'small animal companion' who guides the magical girls, and forms a team with four magical girls of your choice. After confirming each other's teams, start the battle by placing three people as Defender, Attacker, and Supporter. Each magical girl has three command cards with the commands Defense, Attack, and Support written in pairs.

Each team's deck consists of 12 command cards from all four members of the team. The command cards of magical girls who will not participate in the battle this time will remain in the deck, so it is important to form a team while keeping the balance in mind.

Each turn, you choose two of the three command cards in your hand and play them half stacked to use three commands. The Defence command causes the magical girl placed in the Defender to use her special ability Defence Arts. Similarly, the Attack command is used by the Attacker, and the Support command is used by the Supporter. Defenders receive attacks from Attackers, and Supporters support them.

Repeat these steps and win if even one magical girl on the opposing team has their life reduced to 0.

Example of a magical girl:
[Flame and Wings Protection Girl] Suparna Sowaka
Her real name is Karutaya Kureha. She is a guardian girl who specializes in attacks. She transforms with the help of a bird that can control fire. Her special move is Sowaka Karura Burning, which turns flames into giant wings and burns the enemy from two directions.
【炎と翼の護法少女】スパルナソワカ
本名は「歌留多屋くれは（かるたや　くれは）」。
攻撃を得意とする護法少女。炎を操る鳥の力を借りて変身する。
必殺技は、炎を巨大な翼に変え、2方向から敵を燃やし尽くす「ソワカ・カルラ・バーニング」。
description by publisher
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management, Take That, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up

name: Newtopia: Alles auf Anfang
description:
GAME PREPARATION
Each pioneer chooses a character and receives 25 NEWTOPIA points at the start. In addition, 5,000 euros of starting capital is placed on the game board in the communal safe and taken out if necessary. The remaining money remains in the playing box, the "bank", and is taken out when instructed.

GAMEPLAY
The youngest pioneer in the round starts. He rolls the dice and moves forward by the number rolled. If the turn ends on a field with a number, the text for the corresponding field in the event booklet is read out loud and the task is carried out. If another person lands on the same space, the event must be carried out again. At the end of each month there are so-called "decision fields". You have to stay on these fields, even if a higher number is rolled. If there are still numbers left, they expire. If a pioneer reaches the "decision field", all other pioneers have to follow straight away. The person who gets onto the field first reads the task, leads the discussion and makes the final decision. Once the decision has been made, he can be the first to roll the dice again and move on.

GOAL OF THE GAME
It's not about getting to the finish line first. The winner is the person who has collected the most NEWTOPIA points after one year in NEWTOPIA.
categories: Economic, Farming, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Rnewelf TCG
description:
Facing the crisis of natural depletion of the earth, how can you be promoted to restore the earth's resources, reborn the nature's guardian spirit, and revive the mage? Now experience the ancient laws of mutual regeneration and fight for nature.。
7 ways to defeat level territories.
Paradise Lost, Atlantis, the Dark Forest of Magic, the Space Station of the Future, the Underground Lair, the Sun City, etc., fight for the ultimate resurrection mage to defend the energy of the Earth.

When you defeat your opponent capture two territories.
From commoner to junior mage.

Rival Elven cards are resurrected by you to become your new reborn Elven warrior the next time you level up.

"rnewelf tcg: -- Reborn Elf Mages advance to battle "

Game start preparation
Both sides prepare Rnewelf basic cards.
Start the deck, rnewelf elf badge, life source value dice, status indicator dice.

Games start
Throw the elf badge to determine the order of attack

Round starts
Choose your elves to go into battle, use bursts of skills to enhance your own life source and reduce the opponent's life source, manage your tactics and strategies, and choose different attacks and defenses.

Winning ends

Whichever player gets the 6 reward cards first will win.
If the opponent fights and all the Rnewelf Elf Warriors return to the void, and no Rnewelf can appear in the preparation area, our side will win.
When the opponent's card territory has no cards that can be drawn, we win.


—description from the publisher
categories: Animals, Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy, Party Game

name: HATTORI
description:
HATTORI is a two player abstract game from Japan. Players move their pieces alternately orthogonally or diagonally. The winner is the first player to bring three of the neutral pieces home or capture three of their opponent's pieces.

The game is played on a small 5x5 grid. One player has five black tiles, the other has five white tiles, and there are five small green tiles which are neutral.

In opposite corners of the board is a section of three squares, which is each player's base. They start with three pieces in the base and with two adjacent outside. The green tiles are laid diagonally across the board between the bases.

The player's goal is to either bring three of the green tiles onto their own pieces and inside their base, or to eliminate three of their opponent's pieces (thus making it impossible to satisfy the first win condition).

The player pieces move in the direction of the piece's corners. A piece that is turned 45 degrees to the grid therefore moves left or right or up or down the grid, as a Rook in Chess does. A piece aligned to the grid will move diagonally across the grid, as a Bishop in Chess does. A piece can move as far as the player wishes but not through another piece including the neutral tiles.

On their turn, a player can Move, or Throw, or Wait. Whatever the player does, the piece used must be turned 45 degrees at the end of the action (which the publisher reminds us is easy to forget).

When a player moves, they can end their move on a green tile, and place it on their tile.

If a player's tile is empty, and an opponent's tile has a green piece, the player can move their tile onto the opponent's, taking the green tile and eliminating the opponent's piece. This opens up the possibility of tit-for-tat moves, immediately losing a tile. However, pieces inside a player's base are immune from attack.

Instead of moving a tile, a player can Throw a green tile from one piece to another of their own empty pieces. The throw has to be in the tile's orientation, after which it is turned.

Finally, a player can Wait, by simply choosing a tile of their own and turning it 45 degrees. Simply passing is not allowed.

The game was produced in a small tube, with the rules sheet also showing the grid board.
user summary
mechanics: Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Square Grid

name: The Investment Club
description:
Players buy and sell shares in real companies that are leaders in American industry, companies that are listed or traded on the various stock exchanges through which their stock is sold.
