Each set of situations will change every time the game is played, but the object of the game remains the same--to buy low, sell high, and try to corner the market. At the conclusion of the game, the player having the most cash, after selling his stock back to the bank, is the winner.

—user summary

name: Rebel Tide: The American Civil War
description:
Rebel Tide: The U.S. Civil War, 1861-65 is a two-player strategic level game that places you in command of either the USA (Union) or CSA (Confederacy) during the Civil War. Each turn consists of a year, during which multiple card plays occur. These give the players movement, combats, entrenchments, and other actions. At the end of each year, players must make critical decisions on which cards to re-buy in an attempt to win the war outright or to win by placing the other side in a disadvantageous position. Rebel Tide is based on the popular, action-packed Imperial Tide/Pacific Tide game system by Gregory M. Smith, with many combat and strategic decisions to challenge players in just a single evening’s game.

The core of the game is the unique card re-buy system, in which players take their annual production (adjusted for blockades and blockade runners) and decide which cards they need for the upcoming year. Cards not only provide for reinforcements, but allow for movement, combat, and entrenchment. Which cards to rebuy is without question one of the key decisions the player must make to prepare for next year’s operations.

The game has infantry units for all of the major participants, cavalry, and artillery units. Naval operations are mainly abstracted, although the Confederate player must worry about Farragut invading a port from the sea.

Besides the focus on card play, the game features a small footprint (one standard map) and also is designed to be played in just a single evening – estimated at 3 hours for experienced players to fight the entire war.

One new mechanic in Rebel Tide is the Political Track, which is an abstract measure of the support of England and/or France to the Confederacy. If this track reaches the maximum early in the war, it can trigger an early CSA victory.

Another new key mechanic in the game system is the addition of historical Leaders, who range in ability from excellent (5) to poor (2). Bad leaders may be “sacked” and removed from the game and randomly replaced by the expenditure of a movement action. Leaders are vital in advancing after combat and also can add strength to an attack’s total combat power.

A continued mechanic that was very successful in Imperial Tide is the use of Resource Points. Each nationality has a set amount, and there is an option to buy an extra point each year. Although mainly intended to replace infantry strength, they are extremely flexible in that they can be used in limited amounts for movement and combat operations. They can be thought of as a sort of “operational reserve” and should be used judiciously by players.

This game is highly accessible to those familiar with Imperial Tide or Pacific Tide, both designed by Gregory M. Smith. The game system lends itself very well to capturing the bloody and numerous battles of the U.S. Civil War. While Rebel Tide is designed as a two-player gaming experience, an additional option for solitaire play is provided with the inclusion of a Solitaire Bot. This “bot” creates action priorities for the non-human player, and has the advantage of being simple enough to implement without spending an inordinate amount of time as the non-player.

Product Information:

Complexity: 4 out of 10
Playing time: 3 to 4 hours
Solitaire Suitability: 8 out of 10 (Solitaire Bot system)
Players: Two (with option for solitaire play)
Map Scale: Strategic; Abstract
Time Scale: 1 year per Turn; each turn being composed of multiple card plays
Unit Scale: Strategic (Infantry points, Cavalry points, Artillery points, and Leaders)

Game Components:

One Mounted game map, 22” x 34”
One counter sheet, 9/16” counters
Two Player Aid Cards
48 Game Cards (24 per side)
5 Year Cards (double-sided)
Rules Booklet
Two six-sided dice
Box and Lid set

-description from publisher's website
mechanics: Multi-Use Cards, Point to Point Movement

name: Spira Toss
description:
Spira Toss is a unique table-top game that uses a metal ball which you shoot through a spiral loop. The spiral loop can be adjusted to reposition the direction of the ball. The landing point consists of 3-sided squares with either X - O or a number denomination. This allows 2 game versions and either 1 or 2 players.

Game one can be played with one or two players and play like Tic -Tac-Toe.

Game two is played with two players and you are shooting the marble to score 100 points

The pointing system is as such

Column one (Green) +30, +50, +20
Column two (orange) -25, -20, -30
Column three (Purple) +25, -10, +10

The colors do not designate anything but a more colorful game surface. There are two dial number counters on the back of the mini game area

This is definitely not like the easy game play of traditional Tic-Tac-Toe and almost like Toss-Across but you have far less control of what you are using to reach Tic-Tac-Toe.

The added difference of the other games is that this game also has a variation of playing to achieve 100!

—user summary

name: Goo On My Shoe
description: This game is a journey through your neighborhood park! You never know what you will step on. There is a game board, a spinner (Shaped like a roundabout, you know the one shaped like a circle with bars that kids spin so fast, they fly off!) pawn pieces in the shape of gym shoes and 3 types of GOO! Once set, your adventure begins as you travel through the park finding goo obstacles and other park themed happenings. You win by getting to the end with the least amount of GOO on your shoe.

name: Tuk Tuk
description:
Tuk Tuk is a pickup and deliver family puzzle game where each player takes the role of Tuk Tuk driver in Bangkok. Players place cards on the board to create many paths in the city to bring tourists around famous attractions in the city. The player who earns the most money at the end of the day becomes the famous Tuk Tuk driver. With variable player power, riding a Tuk Tuk has never been more fun.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Layering, Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver, Variable Player Powers

name: Schwer von Begriff
description: In this game, players try to read words. These words are encoded in over 150 different ways. This does not make it easy to read the words. A total of 600 word puzzles are available and they can be solved either alone or in a larger group of players.

name: The Idiom Game
description:
This game is base on the complexities of the English Language. Understanding not just the language, but all of the "Idiomatic Expressions" that go along with it. One example would be this:

Yellow meaning Card
What does "built a fire under" mean in this sentence?
The captain "built a fire under" his troops.
a. corrected
b. stirred them to action
c. threatened

The answer is "b" of course!

The game is then played in a similar fashion as Trivial Pursuit. You roll the die, then move the number of spaces on the board. Land on specific colors to match the 4 game question cards. A player continues as long as they answer the question correctly.

The winner is the player that has collected a card from each category (color card) and land on the center (end) space with an exact roll. And then must answer the final question by picking the color card of choice.

—user summary

name: Fryin Flyin Donuts
description:
Think of the game Ants In The Pants in that you need to get your donuts into the fryer similar to getting the ants into the pants. There are twists and turns with this game because the donuts are very light and as you toss them into the fryer, they twist, turn and whirl upwards on a blast of air coming out of the fryer.

The donut chef has a stick that hangs basically upside down so as a donut catches the air it will be forced up onto the stick. The first person to get all 3 donuts into the fryer (stick) wins!

—user summary

name: The Strays
description:
It’s 1944 and the European battlefront is a confusing, disorienting place to be. Lines shift quickly, orders get lost and suddenly you can find yourself behind enemy lines. For some, this is not a barrier but an opportunity… An opportunity to infiltrate lines, inflict chaos upon the enemy and maybe get a little bit of something for yourself while you’re at it.

Enter The Strays. A group of independent-minded soldiers with a mutual goal for personal gain. Their refined skills as leaders, scouts, medics, scroungers and killers will enable them to take out bunkers, outposts, warehouses and labs behind enemy lines well before artillery and the air force level them.

The Strays is a miniature agnostic game. It relies on you to supply the miniatures and terrain for the campaign-based missions contained within. Blank sheets are included for you to create your own missions.

—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, Exploration, Fighting, Miniatures, World War II
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing

name: Lovebirds
description:
Lovebirds is an exciting social deduction game perfect for wedding celebrations and events! Players take on unique roles as they are divided into three teams. The Bride and Groom aim to unite at the end of the game, while the Ex-GF and the Playboy try to separate the bridal party for their own motives. Using their wits and deduction skills, players must identify the traitors and foil their plans. Get ready to put your deduction and deceptive skills to the test in Lovebirds. The ultimate wedding game of romantic mystery and amusement!

In Lovebirds, you and your guests assume hidden roles and join one of three teams: Team Lovebirds, Team Playboy, or Team EX-GF. Each team has a different goal: Team Lovebirds wants to make sure the BRIDE and GROOM end up together happily ever after. While team playboy wants to unite the PLAYBOY with the BRIDE, and team ex-gf wants to unite the EX-GF and GROOM.

To win a game of Lovebirds, you’ll need to use all your charm, wit, and strategy. You’ll have to bluff, flirt, expose, and manipulate your way to victory. But be careful, as your opponents are trying to do the same! Can you figure out who is on your side and who is against you? Can you stop the other teams from interfering with your romantic plans? Can you unite the perfect couple? Find out in Lovebirds, the ultimate game of love and betrayal!

—description from the publisher

name: Hot Pot
description:
When your parents tell you to cook your own food.

In a game of Hot Pot, players will start with an empty bowl. The goal is to get as much food into your own bowl as much as possible. There are certain food items that you don't like or don't eat, which people can load up your bowl for you.

The table is full of raw ingredients. You have to pick the raw food and pop it into the hot pot, cook it before you can take it for yourself. This is where all the action comes into play. The action cards will determine what can be done and when it can be done.

It's a game with a little bit of negotiation, push your luck and alliance building. Sharing is caring.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Alliances, Memory, Negotiation, Push Your Luck

name: Battle Of The Kacoon Sea
description:
Battle Of The Kacoon Sea (空母対空母　決戦カクーノ沖海戦) (Aircraft carrier vs. aircraft carrier decisive battle Battle of Kakuno Gulf) is an early game from the Japanese doujin game publisher KogeKogeDo. It was produced as two versions: Empire and American. A player could play the game as either side, or combine the two versions to play a full game.

The game is based upon the Battle of the Coral Sea, a significant naval battle in the Pacific theatre during World War II. During this battle, the two navies did not actually make contact. Instead, both sides used aircraft launched from carriers to attack the other side. The game simulates this form of combat.

The game is packaged in a large plastic envelope which has the rules, a large playing sheet representing the carriers in an abstract form, and a set of cards for aircraft from each side. The technical drawings of the aircraft are taken from Wikipedia Creative Commons.

In the game, a player must position aircraft on their flight deck and send them up into formations, where they are met and countered by opposing aircraft. The player uses dice to resolve combat between the planes. Then the surviving aircraft must return and land safely. A player can only keep an aircraft in a holding pattern for one turn. If it cannot land after that, it is lost into the sea.

Each player has fighter aircraft and bomber aircraft. The objective is to get the bombers past the fighter defence and to sink the opposing carriers for victory.
user summary
categories: Card Game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Das politische Talent
description:
In this game you found your own parties, put forward candidates, compete against each other in the election campaign and forge coalitions. You collect victory points by being in government for as many rounds as possible and implementing policies. Whoever has the most victory points at the end wins the game.

The game is divided into 3 repeating phases:

Election campaign - You are fighting for seats in parliament.

Formation of government - 2 or more players with a majority form a government.

Game rounds - 3 rounds in which you can implement policies or prepare for the next election campaign.

—description from the designer

In diesem Spiel gründet ihre eure eigene Parteien, stellt Kandidat:innen auf, tretet im Wahlkampf gegeneinander an und schmiedet Koalitionen. Ihr sammelt Siegpunkte, indem ihr möglichst viele Runden in der Regierung seid und Wahlversprechen umsetzt. Wer am Ende die meisten Siegpunkte hat, gewinnt das Spiel.

Das Spiel untergliedert sich in 3 sich wiederholende Phasen:

Wahlkampf - Ihr kämpft um Sitze im Parlament.

Regierungsbildung - 2 oder mehr Spieler:innen mit einer Mehrheit formen eine Regierung.

Spielrunden - 3 Runden in denen ihr Wahlversprechen umsetzen oder ihr euch auf den nächsten Wahlkampf vorbereiten könnt.

—description from the designer (German)
mechanics: Negotiation, Role Playing, Semi-Cooperative Game, Simulation, Voting

name: Villannex ～ 拡張セット「兵力と経済」 (Villanex - expansion set "Military Force and Economy")
description:
Villannex ヴィラネックス～合併競議会～ 拡張セット「兵力と経済」 (Villanex - Merger Competition Council - expansion set "Military Force and Economy") is the very long title on the box front of the expansion set.

This is the Expansion set for the 1st edition of Villannex. These expansions were then incorporated into the 2nd edition Villannex (2nd Edition + expansions).

From the publisher:
This expansion set includes two expansions and one mini-expansion that can be added to the main unit. You can play by adding each expansion or mini-expansion alone, or you can play in combination. Additionally, there are some cards that can only be used when playing two expansions together.

A different location from the previous merger. There was also a village scheduled to be merged here. The problem seems to be the same everywhere, and it seems that the village chiefs are competing against each other.

However, one thing that was slightly different was that these villages had their own military forces and abundant economic power, and they exerted pressure on the merger council. Use these pressures or splash them. Let's aim to become the new village chief!
description by publisher
categories: Card Game, City Building, Expansion for Base-game

name: Planetarium
description:
Fly your planets twice counter clockwise around our sun to win the game. A crossing comet and gravition, generated by magnetic planet balls, creates disturbance.

Die neun Planeten unseres Sonnensystems werden durch Magnet-Kugeln dargestellt. Jeder Spieler führt mehrere Planeten gegen den Uhrzeigersinn um die Sonne. Gravitationsfelder verursachen Störungen und bremsen den geführten Planeten.
Ein Komet kreuzt regelmäßig die Bahnen der Planeten und kann die Planeten zerstören.
Zehn Konstellationskarten geben Siegbedingungen vor, wenn sich mindestens 5 der 9 Planten auf den neun dort gekennzeichneten Positionen befinden.
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement, Race

name: にょきにょきウドラ (NyokiNyokiUdolla)
description:
にょきにょきウドラ (NyokiNyokiUdolla) is a game from Japan, featuring Udolla who is the mascot for Tachikawa, a city inside the western part of the Tokyo metropolis. Udolla is a large white monster with tentacles from the top of its head, which is based upon Tachikawa udon, a local specialty dish.

In the game, players move their own Udolla around Tachikawa, building up love by visiting the sites and attractions in the city to collect heart chips. Players use these chips to build their own Tachikawa, with the most wonderful Tachikawa winning the game.
user summary

name: Roubo no Museu
description:
Roubo no Museu (Portuguese for "Museum Heist" - not to be confused with Alex Randolph's game with the same name in English).

The objective of the game is to be the thief who has the most valuable objects stolen from the museum at the end of the game. Players draw specific roles that have requirements regarding the objects to be stolen. During the game, action cards are drawn that allow movement, the exchange of objects and the eventual return of objects to the museum.

Because of the darkness, players are forced to choose stolen objects only by their silhouette, which can lead to the theft of unwanted items. Players can also steal objects from each other.
The game ends when the action cards run out: the player who has the items with the highest value in their possession - including the bonus for stealing the objects indicated on their role card - wins.

name: Yuck or Yum?
description:
Let's cook up some fun with Yuck or Yum? a rhyming card game with 8 ways to play. Created for toddlers and up!

Cook silly stews, match recipes, find the poop and other games to explore the concepts of rhyme, prediction and deduction plus develop language, memory, observation and more. Includes delicious and disgusting ingredients playfully illustrated by Parker Jacobs (Yo Gabba Gabba!) giving you new ways to bond with your children.

Yuck or Yum? is part of the Small Fries Games range designed to grow with your family. The games and activities are suitable for different stages of development and can be played by children of different ages at the same time.

8 in 1 games and activities for 1 - 4 players. Suitable for ages 18m to 4+. (5 are co-operative, 3 competitive.) The colourful, A6 sized laminated cards are designed for little hands and made in the UK. (FSC card, single use plastic free and Carbon Balanced with the World Land Trust.)

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Humor, Memory
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deduction, Hot Potato, Matching, Memory, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: アメリカンコミックコレクション (American Comics Collection)
description:
アメリカンコミックコレクション (American Comics Collection) is an auction game from Japan. Players are bidding on volumes of comicbooks, trying to complete series. The game has a deck of cards for the four titles with seven volumes each. Each card has symbols, the lower the volume number, the more symbols.

At the end of the game, the winner is the player with the most points, calculated by multiplying the symbols written on the cards and the total number of volumes, plus the remaining cash in hand. Getting the #1 and #7 issues gives high value.

The auction is a straight bid process, but the amount each bid increments is set by the volume number. Completing a series helps, but exhausting other players' funds by pushing the bid up is useful.

—user summary

name: Horrorshow
description:
Horrorshow is a televised romp through a sadistic, otherworldly game show’s studio full of monsters and mayhem where we humans are low on the food chain. The 36 contestants are trying collectively not only to escape, but to do so with enough points to keep the sponsors happy.

Mechanically, you will move your 6 teams of contestants down many corridors to obtain studio cards (representing rooms in the game show's studio) that are worth points. These cards can also combine to spell EXIT, without which those points are worthless. Unfortunately, these studio cards will also often cause a small drop in sanity. So why the hurry to go in? Well, chasing these contestants through the corridors are the insatiable Horrors who will have a strong part to play in dwindling the number of your contestants throughout the game.

You must manage the sanity of your contestants, worry about which contestant completes each corridor and claims the studio card, mind the number of cards left in the movement card deck, and keep up a brisk pace in the corridors ahead of the fast-moving and eponymous Horrors.

And even if you manage to get someone out... you need to hit a particular points threshold to win.

This game can be difficult.

—description from the designer

name: Phil' Up Chuck
description:
This is vaguely based on the game Eat At Ralph's because both games involve expelling the foods you feed him. That is the only similarity because each has a unique mechanical system for the expelling of the food. Phil is a large mechanical head with a small opening for his mouth where you feed him different foods. There are dice and cards involved in the game.

Game Play:
All the p[layers roll their (soft) die at the same time
(There are stipulations)
1. Everyone rolls the same number: Reroll
2. All players that roll the same number skip that turn of feeding Phil
3. The remaining players or the ones that did not roll the same number which could be all four players, then must feed chuck based on the highest number going first

Fill Phil's mouth with the amount of food you rolled on the die
As you fill his mouth he begins to expand until he eventually POPS open!
If you made Phil UP CHUCK, then you flip over one of 4 shirt cards over in front of you. The last one to have a clean shirt wins.

Food types,
chicken, ice cream, pizza and hot dogs

name: Willy Winks
description:
I hope you are not afraid of clowns! This game uses a stand up cardboard clown with white cup eyes and a cup for a mouth! Unlike the traditional game Tiddly Winks, this plays much different and uses a special playing piece that they call a "Wink" which is a wink connected to a wink and each wink side has a different texture on it. There is a smoother side and a courser side depending on which is easier for you to launch.

Unlike Tiddly Winks, you are aiming to get one of these special winks in either of the Clowns eyes or in his mouth. The points are different because the eyes are harder to get the wink into.

Points
10 points for each wink that lands in his mouth
50 points for each wink that lands in his eyes

The winner is the individual player or the team that gets to 150 points.

Parts include the clown and stands - 6 Blue and 6 Red Winks and 3 white target cups (which look like the top of a paint spray can)

name: Opetellaan Sanaralli
description: Examine images and race to find words that start with different letters. Each word scores you a token on your bingo board. The first five-in-a-row wins! The game has two levels – younger players play with picture boards. The game supports learning to read. Special cards provide excitement! There's also a classification game to develop vocabulary and logical thinking skills.

name: Takeaway!
description:
Is the 50's and you discovered the thrilling world of the fast-food takeaway! But also, your adversaries!

Takeaway! is a game for 1 to 4 entrepreneurs, where you must administrate your movement and goods to buy new products and monopolize the market!

The player with their Food Truck at the start of the Road takes a turn.

In your turn you must advance your Food Truck and then make a choice:


Get X Resources of the type shown on the Tile you landed.


Or

Buy the Tile you landed by paying X Resources of the type shown on the Tile.


“X” is the number of empty Tiles you move through! So, plan your movements ahead!

Every Tile you buy is going to give you special actions and benefits through the game, but also, they give you income at the end of the game!

But beware! Tiles with a Food Truck on are blocked for all the players, so be careful with your choices, they could block your ticket to victory!

The player with most money wins the game!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Modular Board, Set Collection, Track Movement, Turn Order: Time Track, Victory Points as a Resource

name: Vliegmachine-Spel
description:
Give each players some counters. Not many if you want a quick game. The more counters you start with, the longer the game. Each player contribute some coins to the pot.
The game is played with a die by two people. The aim of the game is to see who can fly around the world the fastest. One player starts at No. 1, the other at No. 42, so in the opposite direction. Whoever flies past the other gets two tokens from the pot. If the players end up standing on top of each other, the flying tour starts again. If you get to 42 or further, you win the pot. Anyone who lands on the Moon must miss a turn.
Play continues until one player is out of counters.

—user summary
categories: Aviation / Flight, Children's Game, Racing, Travel

name: The Tobruk Game
description:
The Tobruk Game is an Australian post World War 2 strategy War game where two opposing armies set out to capture each others flags.

Each side has 33 pieces of different army ranks, from Generals to Sappers and mines and a spy. The board is a grid and armies deploy their pieces in any arrangement from behind a lake.

Players take turn to advance any piece except mines and their flag. A playing may attack an opposing piece and if their piece is of the same rank or higher then the attack is successful and the enemy piece goes off the board. Mines destroy all attackers except the Sappers. The Spy piece has the ability to move backwards and in attack it is superior to all pieces except mines. If attacked the Spy piece it is defeated by all.

The winner is the side that attacks and captures the enemy's flag.

—user summary

name: SPACE OPEN
description:
SPACE OPEN is fast to learn and easy to play. And yet it always remains exciting because there is a cool mix between strategy and luck.

The Plot:
Cats are tired of dogs playing and having fun. they want to get rid of them, so they shoot all tennis balls into space.
the dogs are going to space to bring their precious tennis balls back.

The game is played in a series of rounds. Every player gets 5 cards and uses them to move on the board. The goal is to collect the tennis balls and to bring them into the spaceships. The first team to fill both spaceships wins the game.

Can play 1 vs 1 (2 players) or 2 vs 2 (4 players).
The cool thing about the game is that every player can decide if he wants to hide or fight. No one is ever really safe until the game is over.

-description from publisher
mechanics: Acting, Catch the Leader, Cooperative Game, Push Your Luck, Race, Team-Based Game

name: Nocturne: Midnight Mini-Expansion
description:
This mini-expansion includes 4 unique double-sided Character Cards, 10 unique Concoction Cards, 3 unique Twilight Goal Cards, and 3 unique Moonlight Goal Cards! With the addition of these additional cards, players will have new ways to play that create new spatial challenges and add completely new gameplay elements! These promo cards are a special THANK YOU to all backers for being early supporters and will not be included with future editions of the game!

—description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Animals, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Puzzle, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Contracts, End Game Bonuses, Grid Coverage, Market, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Set Collection, Solo / Solitaire Game, Square Grid, Variable Set-up

name: Cretaceous Rails: Crowdfunding Exclusive Expansions
description:
The following crowdfunding exclusive expansions are part of the Crowdfunding Exclusive edition of Cretaceous Rails:

Cretaceous Skies Expansion

Take to the skies, adding an aviary to your resort for tons of action chaining opportunities. This expert level expansion adds a high degree of strategic depth with very few additional rules.

Variable Start Expansion

For a little extra variation, draft variable start cards in reverse turn order at the beginning of the game. Each card determines which tourists, dinos, jungle tokens, and cards you start with, as well as how many rails you start with.

End Game Scoring Expansion

End Game Scoring Tiles add extra scoring conditions for more strategic depth.

5th Executive expansion

Explore deeper strategies with the 5th Executive expansion. With four new resort cards that add a fifth executive, open up more opportunities to develop your resort in new and exciting ways.

4 Volcano Miniatures

Bring the cretaceous jungle to life with four beautiful prepainted 3D volcanoes!

-descriptions from the Kickstarter page
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver, Variable Set-up, Worker Placement

name: Hedbanz: Space
description:
From the game box:
Put on your headband, place a card in it and play! Use yes/no questions and your powers of deduction to guess the card in your headband.

Play on-on-one with this Hedbanz single set or combine the headband and cards with your other Hedbanz game for more hilarious challenges!

Contains: 15 character cards, 1 headband, 1 instruction card with suggested questions

name: Sengoku Folio 2: The Battle of Shizugatake
description:
The Battle of Shizugatake is a Japanese doujin (fan-made) game produced by Ludens Faber, and is game 2 of his Sengoku Folio series. The game simulates the battle between Hideyoshi and Shibata.

The game is a typical wargame, with movement and attack values, zones of control, a CRT for combat results, and a turn track.

The game includes a map, rules, historical guide, and mounted counters. The counters need to be cut out.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Ratio / Combat Results Table
publishers: Dōjin Club Ludens Faber (同人会ルデンス・ファベル)

The game is a typical wargame, with movement and attack values, zones of control, a CRT for combat results, and a turn track.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Ratio / Combat Results Table
publishers: Dōjin Club Ludens Faber (同人会ルデンス・ファベル)

name: HAWAII The Card Game
description:
HAWAII: The Card Game is a family-friendly card game that takes players on a Hawaiian adventure. The game combines elements of Go Fish with an educational twist, making it easy to learn and enjoyable for all ages. The theme of the game revolves around exploring the diversity of Hawaii and learning how to pronounce Hawaiian words.
In this game, players take turns asking each other for cards that match certain categories. Players aim to collect sets of cards, and the goal is to collect the most sets.

name: Peace of the Aslan Kingdom
description:
Peace of the Aslan Kingdom is a Japanese doujin (fan-made) game that was produced for sale only at game shows in Japan, such as Tokyo Game Market. To get one you would place an order in advance, the game would be made and brought to the show for you to pick up. It was not for sale to the general public.

This game is based on the anime series Area 88, and deals with mercenary fight pilots fighting for a fictitious kingdom called Aslan.

This particular title uses the "Imperium" system from GDW. One side control the legitimate Aslan forces and the other the rebels. The rebels also have control of the mercenary pilots of Area 88. Both are battling for control of the country.

Game comes with rules, a two-piece map, and counters. Assembly is required.

—user summary
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Cursed Crystals
description:
As a powerful Wizard, you know that the key to unlocking your true potential lies in collecting Crystals and mastering Spells. In the game of Cursed Crystals, you have the opportunity to put your skills to the test and become the most powerful Wizard of them all.

Super easy to learn, challenging to master. Every time you play this game it is different.

Object of the Game:
You are a Wizard who gains power from Crystals and Spells. In order to win you must hold the most power of all Wizards before the 3 Curses are cast.

Card Types:
Crystal Cards: Are the source of your Power Points
Spell Cards: Spells boost your Power Points or have in game functions
Curse Cards: These decide when the game ends

Setup:
The Eldest Wizard shuffles & deals 4 cards to each other Wizard. Keep your cards secret.
Place the remaining cards in a pile face down. This is the “Wizards Library” Pile
The Wizard to the left of the Eldest Wizard goes first.

How to Play:
At the start of your turn take the top card from the Wizards Library to your hand.

Next, choose to Cast a Spell and/or Curse.

Follow the instructions on the Card
When a Spell is cast discard it into the “Forgotten Tomb” Pile
When a Curse is cast place the card aside on the “Altar of Death” Pile.


At the end of their turn a Wizards must only hold a total of 6 Cards. Discard Crystals or Spells into the Forgotten Tomb until your hand only has 6 cards. Curse Cards cannot be discarded at this time.

It is now the next Wizards turn

Cards that say ‘Cast Any Time’ can be used at any stage of the game.

Ending the Game:
A game ends when 3 Curse Cards are in the Altar of Death, or at the end of the turn of the Wizard who drew the last card from the Wizards Library. Once the game ends no more Spells can be cast.
At the end of a game each Wizard must only hold a total of 6 Cards. Place Crystals or Spells into the Forgotten Tomb until your hand only has 6 cards. Curse Cards can be discarded at this time.

Declaring the Most Powerful Wizard:
Add up the value of Power Points in your hand, including any boosts from your End of Game Spells.
The Wizard with the highest total wins.

—description from the designer

name: Baa's Universe
description:
Players will recruit sheep to create a powerful army for battling each other over planets and powerful space gems. Strategies can be built upon various resources such as actions, special actions (Space gems), sheep units, and many more. In each round players will compete with each other for a planet, resources, a set of space gems. Ones with the most powerful army will get planet and a gem,but a player can choose to surrender and bring all the resources they get back to their empire. Both planets and resources are counted as victory points. Who gets to 16 points first will rule the "BAA's Universe"

A player who reached 16 victory points first wins the game.(Planets and resources are counted as victory points which can be earned each round.)

—description from the designer
mechanics: Set Collection, Victory Points as a Resource

name: Legend of the Galactic Heroes: Imperial Chancellor
description:
Legend of the Galactic Heroes: Imperial Chancellor is a doujin (fan-made) game that was only available at the Japanese game shows, such at Tokyo Game Market. It had to be ordered in advance and then you could pick it up at the show. It was not made for the general public.

This game has two sets of rules and can be played in two ways. First, it can be played using rules that are similar to the game Imperium by GDW. Second, it can be played solitaire using the Commando system from Decision Games.

In either game, you are playing the role of the Imperial Chancellor and are trying to accomplish your objectives in the game.

The game includes 2 sets of rules, map, counter sheet, events generator, and a player aid/turn sheet. Assembly is required.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Point to Point Movement, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Pentagona World: L-Gaim Imperium
description:
Pentagona World: L-Gaim Imperium is a doujin (fan-made) game that was only available at the Japanese game shows, such at Tokyo Game Market. It had to be ordered in advance and then you could pick it up at the show. It was not made for the general public.

This game is played using rules that are similar to the game Imperium by GDW. It is a wargame where one side controls the planets in their rebellion against the Anti-Poseidal Army.

The game includes a set of rules, a four-part map, 2 counter sheet, 1 force organizational sheet, and a player aid/turn sheet. Assembly is required.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Point to Point Movement, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Tippel-Brüder
description:
There are four starting places on the board. Each player takes 4 figures of the same color and places them in the starting position of the same color. The players take turns to roll and move. When moving, one skips over all other figures and only counts the empty spaces. The winner is the player who brings his 4 vagabonds to the finish line first.

One can only start after rolling a 1 or 6. Whoever rolls 1 places a figure on space 1 of their driveway. Whoever rolls 6 moves forward 6 spaces and comes to their own intersection and can roll the die again. On the roll of a "one, he may immediately jump to the finish. On any other roll he has to enter the round course around the board.

If a figure lands on a space with a figure of the same color, it sits next to it, rolls again. But if a figure hits a figure of a different color, it is pushed off the path. The pushed figure must go into the starting place at the next intersection behind, even if it is a foreign starting place.

After completing the circuit, the figure has to stop at its stopping point. Only the next time a 1 is rolled it is allowed to jump from the stopping point to the finish. As long as a figure stands at its stopping point, subsequent figures of its color may jump over it's back to the finish with every throw that extends beyond the stopping point. If a figure of another color is sitting at the stopping point, a figure of the color of the stop point is blocked and may not jump over it to the finish.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Static Capture, Track Movement

name: Acheron's Fall
description:
Put yourself in the shoes of a captain of the human or alien fleet. Use your skills to overcome your enemy in frantic and exciting battles between large spaceships. Choose a side and fight to prevent the blockade from falling or to overcome it. An officially licensed game from Corvus Belli with the factions and sides represented in their universe.

—description from the designer

name: Runebeasts: Deck-Building Game
description:
In the Runebeasts Deck-Building Game, capture and summon creatures in your quest to be the ultimate beast-tetherer.

Runebeasts gives players the chance to evolve their beasts to make them stronger. Players can even try to catch the coveted legendary runebeasts! To win the game, players will have showdowns with their opponents around the table.

In this twist on classic deck-builders, each player will start with an asymmetric deck full of beasts. They will use those beasts on their turn to fight and attempt to collect more powerful beasts in the market, to collect gems and get bonuses, or to power up and evolve their beasts!

Each of the 10 different beast types provide different benefits, so you can customize your deck to fit your play-style. Will you roll the die and take your chances with legendary beasts, or take a more conservative approach?

Halfway into the game, players will start to engage in showdowns; programming their beasts in their hand and gaining points for every battle won. Earn 10 points to win the game!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Market, Multi-Use Cards, Variable Set-up

name: Big Business: The Famous National Money Game
description:
This vintage game was released by Transogram in 1948. They actually labeled it their "Gold Medal Game". The game centers around finances and provides each player with $100,00 to see who ends up with the most money! The publishers claim that it is The Newest National Money Game". This business game is played as each player is given $100,000 and then advances around the board. Assets are tracked to eventually determine the winner. You can also play the quick version of the game where as soon as one player goes bankrupt all other players then count their money to see who has the most, the winner!

—user summary

name: Big 6 Sports Games
description:
This game features 6 different sports, with some of them featuring iconic athletes, like Mickey Mantle and Verne Gagne! It has some collectible items, like cards of Mickey Mantle, so rare. This game was released by Gardner in 1957, during the key parts of Mickey Mantle's incredible career. This game is actually 6 different games in one, each with their own set of rules, unique game boards and ways to win. For example, the baseball game (by far the most popular of the 6 games) is played with a spinner with each of the 2 players participating as a team. After 9 innings the team with the highest score wins the game, just like baseball! The spinner has an awesome picture of Yankees legend Mickey Mantle.

—user summary

name: Bottom of the 9th: Eric Lang
description:
Featuring Eric Lang as a Utility Player
Playing for the Unpub Prototypes

Location: +1/-1 swing
Direction: Reroll swing
Both: MVP or any 2 (Loc./Dir.)
MVP: Playing the pawns. Roll the pitch dies (this does not chnage the pitch). If ball, you gain 1 MVP from the first player in your lineup. If strike, gain the second player's MVP. If paints the corner, gain any player's MVP.
Trait: use the trait of the runner on first base.
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Real-time, Sports
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Simultaneous Action Selection, Solo / Solitaire Game, Variable Player Powers

name: ROMPANION
description:
ROMPANION (ロンパニオン) is a party game from Japan, in which players tell a story and then discuss it to reach a conclusion that is not just black or white.

The designer was inspired by the idea of create a more nuanced outcome to a discussion and produced a game with a gradual scale in five stages, with matching colours and symbols. A player draws a combination of cards and tells a story based upon the prompts on the cards. The other players discuss the story with a view to bringing players to accept their analysis.

The player that brings more people to their view is the winner.
user summary
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Word Game

name: Bad Ideas (Lead to Better Ones)
description:
Bad Ideas (lead to better ones) is a card game that develops creativity through play. When the cards are combined together, they create a randomized design problem to solve. Then it's up to you and the other players to think of the most inventive solution. The game can be used in for corporate brainstorming, education or played with friends.

How to Play
tools
use the bundled dry erase markers on the blank erasable cards or markers on paper

timekeeping
use a smartphone timer, egg timer, or anything that allows custom times between 1 and 5 minutes.

play
choose a ‘PLAY MODE’ for gameplay and judging details

winning
after the round is over a winner is chosen by blind vote:

assign numbers to the players ideas
write your choice on a blank whiteboard card or paper scrap
reveal your choices a the same time and tally them up
you can’t vote for yourself!


wild cards
if a ‘draw 2’ card is flipped over during play, 2 new cards should be pulled from the deck and used instead

skill level
if you want to really practice your drawing skills, multiply the play time listed by 3

Play mode: Iterate
cards
all players use the same set of 3

play

flip the user card and sketch any product for that user [1m timer]
flip the goal card and modify your idea to fit that goal [2m timer]
flip the constraint card and modify your idea to fit that new constraint [3m timer]
take turns sharing all 3 ideas


voting
judge players on how creatively their idea has evolved

Play Mode: Blue Sky
cards
each player is dealt their own set of 3

play

flip over all the dealt cards at once
sketch out a product idea that helps the user achieve their goal while accounting for the constraint card [5m timer]
take turns sharing your ideas


voting
judge players on how creatively they interpret all 3 cards dealt to them
mechanics: Drawing, Line Drawing, Paper-and-Pencil, Storytelling, Voting

name: Lightning Strikes!: The World Wars of the 20th Century
description:
Lightning Strikes! gives players the chance to write a completely new narrative of 20th-century world history. In the full campaign game players create a new global history by managing their countries from the outbreak of war in 1914 through 1954, navigating potentially several world wars, as well as intervening lulls of global peace, while overseeing the development of exciting and devastating new weapons, until one player’s power bloc emerges victorious. There are also many shorter scenarios (from single campaigns to an entire world war) for players with limited time or focused interest. Lightning Strikes! is based on the legendary World in Flames family of detailed wargames.

—description from the publisher
categories: Wargame, World War I, World War II
mechanics: Area Movement, Impulse Movement, Multi-Use Cards

The set consists of a set of counters and a rulebook.

The set comes with a counter sheet and rules.

name: Марсианский десант (Martian Landing)
description:
Марсианский десант ("Martian Landing") is a game dealing with the invasion of Mars by airborne forces from Earth. One side plays the landing force, consisting of infantry with heavy weapons, and the other controls the garrison, which consists of vehicles.

The goal of the game is for the paratroops to capture all communication centers and establish a link with the main invasion force.

The game comes with a map, sprues for tanks and infantry, gaming markers, damage tokens, and rules.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Turn Order: Progressive

name: Европа: Тевтонский удар (Europe: Teutonic Strike)
description:
Europe is a strategy game that offers a journey into the depths of historical fiction.

Each player controls an empire and tries to improve it by capturing new territory, building settlements and fortresses, developing the city and crafts, and improve their equipment.

There are five games in the series, each dealing with a particular historical time in Europe:


Roman Sword
Novgorod Glory
Birth of Normandy
Crown of France
Teutonic Strike


Each game includes a board, counters, cards, tokens, plastic figures, and rules.

—user summary
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Events, Hexagon Grid, Income

name: The Three Chipmunks Big Record
description:
This is an awesome game, and even historic, since it was released prior to the big fame achieved by Alvin And The Chipmunks. It was made by Hasbro in 1960. It is a new surprise game, who wins the big record.

Players advance around the game board using the spinner. The first player to finally enter The Big Record Circle is declared the winner!

name: Мехбат2 (Mecha Battle 2)
description:
Mecha Battle 2 is a predecessor to ZOD.

The game is about mecha combat in the future, much like Battletech. Competing corporate powers fight for supremacy in urban ruins, with infantry, tanks, aircraft and large robots.

The game comes with plastic infantry, mecha, and bases, plus unit data cards, a card factory, dice and rules.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Line of Sight, Simulation

name: Red Wingopoly
description: This is a monopoly game made for the town of Red Wing, Minnesota, it is a first edition that was presented to the Red Wing Area Chamber Of Commerce. This is the lovely town that makes Red Wing Shoes and Red Wing Pottery!

name: Al-Kisah
description:
Al-Kisah, meaning 'The Story' in Arabic, is a highly competitive 18-card game that showcases a diverse array of folklore, fairytales, and stories from various cultures. Each deck in the game focuses on a specific culture, featuring unique characters and narratives. The scoring system is heavily based on the characters and stories within these folklore.

The objective is to accumulate the highest score. Players will gain points from the cards in the shared tableau that match the suit of their hand cards at the game's conclusion. This not only requires strategic thinking, but also provides the ultimate proving ground for players to demonstrate their adaptability and foresight through card placement and hand management.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck Construction, End Game Bonuses, Hand Management, Hidden Victory Points, Tile Placement

name: Tuamotu
description:
Only the light provided by the Tuputupuas Messengers can repel the darkness that is trying to harm your Tikis.

In Tuamotu, you summon the various Tuputupuas Messengers embodied by Rays, Sharks, Turtles and Geckos to transmit the protective light to you.

Will you have enough light before darkness falls on you?

To win, you'll need to collect 25 shells and avoid holding cards with high Tiki values.

To do this, players will have to match pairs of cards to make the Tuputupuas messengers appear.

As soon as you put a pair of cards together, you win shells and you can apply effects to all the players (discard cards, return shells, donate a card, block cards from the island, renew the island).

On their turn, players can take an island card, pay for a shell on an island card, pay for two shells and discard a card, pay for 5 shells and renew the island. He can then place the pairs of cards in front of him and apply the effects in order. He may not have more than 3 cards in his hand at the end of his turn.

The game ends when a player has collected 25 shells. The scores are then determined by subtracting the Tiki values of the remaining cards in hand from the number of shells collected.

-description from publisher
